PARA.TAB: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Cook, the industry minister. It is sort of a dorothy dixer because I wanted to give the minister the chance to assure the Senate that his colleagues Stephen Smith and Wayne Swan are wrong and that his proposed innovation statement is not `a bronze medal strategy' and not `absolutely lacking in substance'. But, more importantly, Minister, I ask you: how can industry have confidence in you when, despite all the hype, this innovation statement is delayed month after month after month, is still regarded by your colleagues as woefully inadequate, and has in fact had to have been taken out of your hands by the Prime Minister, ultimately to be delivered by him? Doesn't this debacle further demonstrate a government that has run out of ideas and also of steam?
—Thank you, Madam Deputy President. This is the first time I have been in the chamber since you have been in the chair. Congratulations to you on that.

PARA.TAB: Turning to the question, the first thing I can say about this is it is a pity this is not an economic question because I understand the much vaunted debt truck broke down on the hill to Lawson in the Blue Mountains today, which just shows that not only is it a fraudulent scam but also they cannot even maintain the engine of an imported lorry of lies!

This question is about the innovation statement. If the sincerest form of flattery is imitation, then the opposition is engaging in flattery indeed when it comes to the government. I posted at last year's ANZAAS meeting in Geelong the intention of this government to bring down an innovation statement this year. Just about a month ago the opposition decided to get into the act and it announced that its next headland speech would be on innovation. It was only about nine or 10 months too late from the initiative taken by the government, but I congratulate the opposition on trying to catch up to us. It is a commendable effort by them.

I hope that the outcome of the 2,000-odd consultations that I and my colleague ministers have had with Australian business and with Australian scientists and technicians around Australia and which in the middle of the year we published as a compendium of all the views submitted to the government across the board is of some use to the opposition as a resource document when they are scratching for an idea to include in their innovation statement, the next headland speech.

To the rest of these questions, I could say you would like that to be the case, Senator Hill. Pity for you it is not. Pity for you that a reporter in the Australian newspaper yesterday wrote a column which he did not bother to check with my office about. If he had done that, he would have found out what the truth of the matter was, rather than reporting some gossip from apparently the passage and alleyways of this building.

The facts are, of course, that there has been no such reaction by the caucus committee or, indeed, by any factional grouping in this parliament in the manner reported in yesterday's Australian newspaper. One of the reasons why there has not is that I have actually not told anyone what will be in the innovation statement. Because I have not told them, they cannot form a view about it, and because they cannot form a view about it, they cannot grade it as to whether it is a bronze medal or a gold medal. But I might say that this parliament can look forward to it being a gold medal, because it will be a substantial statement.

The fundamental point the government is driving at here is that, since we have opened the Australian economy and made the Australian economy more internationally competitive, we are looking at ways of making Australia a winner in the international marketplace. Innovation—the bringing together of Australia's long-established reputation in science and technology as a leading nation in the world in that field with our entrepreneurial skill and our commercial sector—will ensure that Australia is a winner in the international economy, that we think innovatively at all levels of management, that we use our science and technology base to create new ideas and new products from those ideas, and that Australians can look forward to better, more intelligent jobs in a more competitive industry at the leading edge in the world.
That is what the innovation statement is about. That is what you are trying to catch up with. Please try very hard, but we will be there on the day. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is all words. After 18 months in the job—and Labor nearly 13 years in office—just share your secret. Tell us what specific ideas you have to encourage Australian innovation. You are the minister. Let us hear your ideas.

—You will just have to wait until the statement. I know you would like a preview. I know you would like me to tell you my ideas now so you can pinch them and put them in your next headland speech. I will tell you what the biggest joke in the press gallery is when I talk to economic writers who actually know about this field of economics. The biggest joke is: `The opposition are light-years behind you, Minister, in terms of the evolution of the next generation of industry policy thinking.'

PARA.TAB: This statement has not been put off; it has been delayed in order to make it a bigger and more effective blockbuster which will blow right over the opposition and drive us back into office for yet another term. Worry about that, Senator Hill; that is your problem, because you have been a most uninventive science shadow minister and one who is a joke around the halls of science in this country. That is your problem. We are not going to help you solve it. We will solve it in the interests of the Australian community and the Australian electorate, and you will have to wait until the statement comes down to find out what it contains. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, Senator Cook. I draw his attention to the fact that, in one of its rare statements on science, the opposition has claimed that the government is not supporting Australian scientists and that the quality of Australian science is declining. So I ask the minister if he can inform the Senate of current information about the state of Australian science and scientists?

—I had the honour to open yesterday's 64th ANZAAS conference, which is a pre-eminent gathering of Australian and New Zealand scientists; and the opening of this prestigious event is, in fact, the right place for the science minister to have been. I was able to point out the clear fact that the latest OECD figures now rank Australia fourth in the OECD in terms of public sector expenditure on research and development expressed as a percentage of GDP. We were ranked seventh out of 25 on that index, but last year Australia moved ahead of France, the Netherlands and Germany and is now only led by the three Scandinavian countries. That is a matter for celebration for Australia. We have a strong public sector commitment to science. We are ranked fourth in the developed world in terms of public sector expenditure.

PARA.TAB: Unlike the opposition, we have a real and longstanding commitment to science. The real value of total spending on science since we came to office in 1983 has increased by 56 per cent—that is, in real dollars our commitment to science has gone up by 56 per cent compared with that of the opposition when they were in power.

Last year I announced at ANZAAS a study to benchmark Australia's science and innovation system. The study, conducted by the Bureau of Industry Economics in consultation with my department, the Australian Research Council, the Industry, Research and Development Board and the science academies, compared Australia with more than 20 OECD and Asian countries in order to assess how we rate in the world. The study is close to publication, but I can reveal some of the data that has come out.

The study paints a picture of Australia as a reasonably well balanced and, for its size, an influential science country which remains much more sophisticated than the science systems emerging within the regional economies. The study has some particularly interesting information about human resources in science. Australia now has a higher than OECD average concentration of researchers, scientists and engineers engaged in research and development. The growth rate in the numbers of students graduating in science and engineering in Australia is one of the highest in the world. The proportion of women graduating in science and engineering is now one of the highest in the world, as is the number of women moving into research in the public and private sectors. The age profile of scientists and engineers is younger in Australia than is the case in most developed countries. The concentration of research and development personnel in our total work force has increased by 25 per cent since the 1980s and is higher than the median for the OECD economies.

One of the myths that circulate is that there is a brain drain from Australia of scientists going overseas. The facts are that every year for the past 10 years there has been an increase of scientists and engineers migrating to Australia—a net increase of some 30,000 scientists and engineers during that period. That is a brain gain, not a brain drain. There is a waiting list for scientists wanting to come here.

I could go on, but, quite significantly, when this study is fully presented, it will show that under the administration of this government we have spent the public dollar wisely to increase our capacity as a nation in science, engineering and innovation, which are key drivers of economic growth and which create intelligent and rewarding jobs for Australians. As a consequence of our strength in this field, we are now developing a whole string of new industries which will provide intelligent and challenging jobs for the next generation of Australians and make sure the Australian economy is a strong economy in this, the highest growth area of the world. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to Senator Cook, but as Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the minister to the Prime Minister's claim yesterday that Australia's short-term interest rates `are the seventh lowest in the OECD area', thereby putting us in the middle of the field. Is it not a fact, however, based on the Economist magazine information drawn on by the Prime Minister, that Australia's nominal short-term interest rates are the fourth highest of any industrialised OECD country; our nominal 10-year government bond yields are the fourth highest; our real short-term interest rates are actually the third highest when we use the underlying inflation rate, which is the one which the government constantly claims is the most appropriate and accurate measure of inflation; and we have the second highest real government bond yields, which is the rate which most influences our interest rate environment? I seek leave to table the figures on which those are based. (Time expired)

—I have a copy of the Economist magazine here, too. It does verify what the Prime Minister said to the House of Representatives yesterday. It does show Australia as being in the middle of the field of the OECD in terms of short-term interest rates.

PARA.TAB: The reason why this debate started in the first place was the crass allegation by the opposition that Australia had the highest interest rates in the world. That is what you said.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another lie!

—That was the lie that was propounded in Australian politics. What we have just heard from Senator Short is a list of interest rates across the board which proves that it was a lie and that it was not true—even out of the mouth of the Treasury spokesman for the opposition!

PARA.TAB: I am happy to table my copy of the Economist magazine so that people can read it for themselves. I do not necessarily want to debate it, but the point is simply this: your leaders—if I can go back through Hansard, Madam Deputy President, through you—and I believe you, too, Senator Short, said that Australia had the highest interest rates in the world. That is not true—repeat, `That is not true.' Because you let this mislead us all, why should anyone ever believe you again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I seek leave to table the figures on which my question was based.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister has used the headline `rate of inflation' to justify the Prime Minister's assertion. Is the minister now in effect saying that Prime Minister Keating and Treasurer Willis have been flagrantly misleading Australians not only about our high interest rates but also about our high inflation, which in headline terms, rather than underlying, which you have now completely dismissed, is the second highest in the OECD, the second highest of any industrialised country in the world? If so, what does the government intend to do to correct and address this emerging high inflation problem?
—Some people just cannot lie straight in bed and I guess you are one of them, Senator Short. The underlying inflation rate is the right comparison.
—Madam Deputy President, I find that offensive and I ask the minister to withdraw.
—I withdraw. Let us get these facts very clear. Australia has currently low inflation rates by historical standards. Australia is in the middle of the field on international comparisons.
—Not true; not true. That is a lie and you know it.
—Withdraw that. Don't be such a hypocrite. You asked for the other remark to be withdrawn.
—Order! Senator Short, withdraw that please.
—Madam Deputy President, I did not say the minister was lying. I said that what he said was a lie. As I understand it, that is not unparliamentary.
—I think that should be withdrawn. It is casting imputations on the minister.
—I withdraw and substitute `untrue'.

—I thank Senator Short for being a gracious and charming individual. When John Howard was Treasurer, the housing loan rate for Australia was 12.5 per cent. The current bank housing rate is 10.5 per cent. That is a comparison of who is better—you or us. We have a lower rate than you had. When John Howard was Treasurer, the building societies rate was 13.9 per cent. The current rate is 10.5 per cent. When John Howard was Treasurer, the cash rate was 12.9 per cent. The current cash rate is 7.5 per cent. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Are you aware of comments made at the Queensland rural women's conference at Longreach that this government treats rural women as second-class citizens? Can you advise what the government's response is to this statement?

—Yes, I am aware of the statements made at this recent conference that this government treats women as second-class citizens. I thought it was a bit rich because the comments were made by the National Party member for Kennedy, Bob Katter. In terms of treating women like second-class citizens, I refer all senators, and indeed any other interested people, to the House of Representatives Hansard when Mr Katter quite recently opposed the government's equal opportunity legislation for women. Mr Katter gave as his major reason for opposing the equal opportunity legislation—and I quote from the House of Representatives Hansard—`A woman's place is in the home.'
—That's what Paul Keating said in his maiden speech.

—The member for Kennedy said it, Senator, and very recently. You are referring—and I am familiar with it, Senator—to the Prime Minister's maiden speech. What I can say to you is: a great many things have moved on since then, except the National Party.

PARA.TAB: It is a nonsense to accuse this government of ignoring the needs of women and families that are suffering from exceptional drought. Unlike the previous coalition government—and the record shows it—which did absolutely nothing, this government has moved significantly to increase the participation of women in a whole range of areas. We have made real progress in working with rural women to increase their participation. We have made significant strides.

I said recently that, since assuming responsibility for this portfolio, the lack of women involved in rural policy making, particularly with the myriad of boards in this portfolio, is of real concern to me. It is not only unfair to exclude 30 per cent of farmers—which is what women are in rural Australia—but it also works against our best interests. The government has taken a number of significant steps to address this.

A rural women's unit has been established in my department and a national women's coordinator appointed. We provided funding to support the first international women in agriculture conference held in Melbourne last year—to the best of my knowledge, the first in the world. We also co-sponsored the first national rural women's forum. The secretary to my department is establishing a rural women's consultative committee to advise on what other measures we need to take. A strategy to address the number of women on government bodies is being developed.

We have appointed, for the first time, women to chair the selection committees that operate in this portfolio that make recommendations to government on those appointments. We are working with industry organisations on what we all need to do to increase the representation of women on industry groups and bodies. Women are already well represented in important areas of land care and rural financial counselling. Senators may be interested to hear that a recent Victorian study showed that the higher the percentage of women in land care groups, the more effective those groups were, which is a clear argument in favour of making sure that we include women in the whole range of groups and processes to do with rural Australia. The government, rural women and industry are all working together successfully in this area and we will continue to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, are you aware that at the same conference the statement was made that it was about time rural women forced the Prime Minister to listen to them?

—Yes, that was the second piece of nonsense that Mr Katter introduced into that conference. Rural women will find that a big laugh because, as I have said, and as I have publicly acknowledged on a number of occasions, the most significant input into the drought package prepared by this government came from rural women. The Prime Minister, on a number of visits—they are mounting up—to rural Australia in recent times, confirmed that that has been the position. The reason I make that point is quite simple: over 10,000 farm families have taken advantage of the government's drought package. John Anderson, the shadow minister for primary industry, himself concedes—
—Got a hint there? Come on, the girls have given you a hint.

—I will give you the transcript, Senator. He concedes that most of the families in New South Wales would not qualify for assistance under the coalition's drought policy, saying, `If we introduced it, we would have to throw thousands of families currently receiving it off the assistance tomorrow.' (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Trade, Senator McMullan. I refer the minister to the appalling environmental record of BHP at Ok Tedi and the damage the attempted subversion of the legal process is doing to Australia's standing as an environmentally sensitive and responsible corporate world citizen. I also refer the minister to the fact that Australian companies are major investors in the proposed Lihir gold mine in Papua New Guinea, to be insured by the government-owned Export Finance and Insurance Corporation. Can the minister guarantee that EFIC's involvement in this project is subject to the strictest environmental guidelines and an absolute assurance from the investors that BHP's behaviour at Ok Tedi will not be repeated at Lihir?

—While EFIC actually is not in my portfolio responsibilities—it is within those of my colleague the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, Senator Cook—he has confirmed my understanding that there will be environmental impact assessment of EFIC's involvement in accordance with the normal requirements. I have no intention of getting involved in your comments about BHP and Ok Tedi but, in regard to the specifics of your question, that is the answer.
—Can the minister confirm that this will also be the rule for future investments by Australian companies overseas?

—It is, of course, not for the Australian government to conduct environmental impact assessments of Australian corporate investment. The environmental impact assessment is because of EFIC's involvement as an Australian government agency. If the Australian company is investing in another country, the responsibility for the environmental protection in that country is, of course, the sovereign responsibility of the host country, not ours; any more than we would expect the United States to conduct environmental impact statements about investments in Australia, which we would think would be an abrogation of our sovereignty and we would not allow.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade, Senator McMullan. Minister, yesterday in this place you referred to the CEDA survey, which identified `an extraordinary variety' of trade barriers confronting Australian exports. You would be aware of the concern in the community that one such barrier is the use of unreasonable quarantine procedures to keep our products out of markets. What is the government doing and what more can be done by the government to tackle these non-tariff barriers to Australian products?

—It is true that for a great many of Australia's agricultural industries, particularly those in the horticultural sector, their future viability hinges absolutely on their capacity to export. In these industries, barriers established under the name of quarantine, which do not have a scientific justification as a quarantine barrier, are major impediments to export.
—Did you watch Four Corners last night?

—I am talking about exports from our country overseas. If you do not agree with this, I would be very interested to hear. In many countries it is a particular export interest, and this is an issue which my colleague the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and I and our respective officials have been working on very hard. I am stunned that a representative of the National Party does not think our trying to get our agricultural produce exported is a good idea, but you are welcome to have that view, and I am pleased to have it on the record.

PARA.TAB: The government has before it a very long list of well over 50 barriers established on purported quarantine grounds by our trading partners, and we are establishing priorities to try to get our cherries, grapes, and other such fruit, and tomatoes into Japan. We are also trying to get oranges, apples, table grapes, et cetera into Korea. If I recall correctly, I think it was the Premier, Mr Groom, on behalf of the Tasmanian state government, who led a delegation to Korea recently on this question of trying to get access for Tasmanian fruit to Korea because he was concerned about the unreasonable quarantine barriers that were being erected. I think that is correct and, if it is correct, I congratulate him on that initiative. It is something he should have done, and I am sure that he will apply that same principle consistently elsewhere.

We also have concerns about, and significant activities about, attempts to get apples, pears and citrus fruit into China, and the list could go on and on. As more and more of Australia's agricultural industries become more export oriented, this is going to become an increasingly important issue. As a result of the Uruguay Round reforms, protectionist quarantine restrictions have become more exposed in these countries.

Through the activities of our diplomatic and trade representatives, and our quarantine and DPIE representatives, we are working very hard to open these markets previously closed by quarantine restrictions. Of course, any country, including Australia, is permitted to impose quarantine restrictions where they are justified on scientific grounds, and we cannot justify seeking to have those overturned where they have a proper scientific basis. It is very vital to a country such as Australia, which exports five times more food than it imports, that these international disciplines are applied and that agricultural barriers are not therefore artificially allowed to be raised against our products.

It is a principal issue of concern to the Cairns Group and to our partners in the Cairns Group. It also relates to some of the concerns about APEC, and why we are trying to make sure that our activities there are comprehensive. We have a range of processes under way through the government—bilaterally, multilaterally and regionally—to tackle these individual quarantine problems, including some of the technical quarantine talks which we hold regularly with Japan and other bilateral negotiations, within which we receive valuable support from the industry.

I welcome the fact that we are making some progress in Korea and Thailand. In Japan and the United States recently we have been able to make progress to get more access, particularly for our citrus fruit but across a range of other products as well, and it is very important to the future of those industries. The export figures that those successes reflect represent your starting points for industries shifting from a solely domestic focus to exports, and it will continue to be a priority for us to try to create these opportunities and the consequent prosperity for our rural communities. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Minister, yesterday you told the Senate that, according to the consultants Booz-Allen and Hamilton, some 30 per cent of the performance gap between Australian meat processors and the US competitors is due to factors within their control. Is it a fact that Booz-Allen and Hamilton estimated that closing this gap would save the beef industry at least $750 million a year? Does the minister agree that savings of this magnitude could well have been sufficient to keep open those Queensland meatworks which have closed in recent days because they are uncompetitive? Is it a fact that Booz-Allen and Hamilton identified the lack of labour market reform under your government as the major barrier to achieving these cost reductions and therefore keeping the 2,000 Queensland meatworkers' jobs lost in recent days?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is no, Senator Boswell. I had the Booz-Allen report with me yesterday; I do not have it in front of me today, but from memory the estimated quantum of savings was about half that figure. It equated to around $50 per head in terms of a price to producers. The Booz-Allen report did find precisely what I said. The AAP report from question time yesterday accurately reported what I said. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Collins said the consultants' report showed that up to 70 per cent of cost disadvantage suffered by Australian beef producers was out of the hands of processors. It is, in fact, due to factors such as the distance to market, for example, and the types of cattle that are produced for particular markets—
that is, grass fed as opposed to grain fed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing to do with labour markets!

—No, Senator. What I also said was that the report did identify work practices that have to be addressed. It listed those as one of the major factors of the 30 per cent of factors that could be improved in the Australian meat industry—which has been acknowledged by the government—rather than the 70 per cent that cannot be addressed.
—When are you going to address it?

—If Senator Boswell bothered to read the Booz-Allen report—I know you haven't read it either, Senator Macdonald—he would find that the Booz-Allen report also found that those issues were being addressed in terms of the Australian meat industry. One of the things he should know about AMH, which is the particular works that are being effected by these temporary closures at the moment, is that work is well under way on negotiating new enterprise agreements for those works.

PARA.TAB: I am saying that a range of factors is responsible for the current downturn, and the industry has correctly made those public. The major reasons are a flat international market and reduced profit margins exacerbated by rising domestic prices and, as Senator Boswell acknowledged yesterday, influenced by the drought and high feed grain prices that are a result. They are the major reasons, including of course the appreciation of the value of the Australian dollar of around five per cent.

What Senator Boswell is trying to perpetuate in relation to industrial relations and the workers being singly responsible for the temporary closure of these meatworks—which, I might add, has forever been a feature of the meat industry in Australia because of the seasonal nature of it—is nonsense. Senator Boswell, you should acknowledge that work is under way to address changing those work practices and AMH, at their meatworks in Rockhampton and a number of their other meatworks, are trialling now new arrangements, in cooperation with the unions—I know you do not want to hear this—and under the supervision of the Industrial Commission, to establish new enterprise agreements for those meatworks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Industry Commission, in a later report on meat processing, identify exactly the same barriers to improving the competitiveness of the industry as highlighted by the Booz-Allen and Hamilton report and make recommendations for sweeping reforms to the meat industry's industrial relations system? Why do you claim to have fixed the industrial relations system? Is it not a fact that an independent report commissioned by the Department of Industrial Relations found that progress in workplace reform in the export meat processing sector has generally been limited with little to show in terms of widespread and quantifiable increase in productivity and efficiency and that enterprise bargains agreed to date in many cases have been little more than a means to achieve a general wage increase?

—It is true that the Booz-Allen report did demonstrate, when this government in fact initiated those examinations of the meat industry, that this government had indeed inherited the archaic work practices that you lot did nothing about for 23 years of conservative government, just as you were terrified to touch the waterfront in the whole of that time. You did absolutely nothing about it. The facts are, Senator Boswell, even if you will not acknowledge them, that the AMH company is, in fact, as you speak, engaged in an exercise with the unions and the Industry Commission in negotiating new enterprise agreements for those works.

—My question is to the Minister for Family Services. Can the minister provide details of how the federal government's home and community care program has improved the quality of life for older people over the last 10 years?

—The home and community care program is one of this government's proud achievements. It is a joint program with the states and it has been the key to keeping older frail Australians out of institutions and to assisting people with disabilities in the same way. What we know from those elderly people, and also people with disability, is that they would much prefer to live out their lives in their own homes.

PARA.TAB: The government introduced the home and community care program in 1984-85. That was a very important step towards dealing with the chaos left by the previous coalition government and its very ad hoc system of care, which was based on institutional care. The government has increased the funding for that program from $70 million when the program was started to over $423 million this financial year—something like a 243 per cent increase in real terms. There are something like 7,000 projects operating from 4,600 outlets, and they cover over a million people a year—220,000 people a month. We know that those people are being assisted in a whole variety of ways.

Added to that, this year we have seen a significant increase in a new addition to that program—the community aged care packages. It is another initiative which is a complete package for in-home care needs for the frail aged.Those numbers have gone from 527 in 1992-93 to 4,195 in 1995-96, with an extra $34.8 million. As I have said already, we do know that people would much prefer to live out their lives in their homes.

It is sometimes said that Australia is an uncaring country for its elderly people, but I need to remind people, including the opposition, that only about 12 per cent of elderly Australians finish up in nursing homes or hostels. By my calculations, that is 88 per cent who live out their lives at home supported by their families, and very often managing for themselves to the very end.

What we also know is that many of the people who are elderly in this country are not frail or debilitated and they are able to contribute fairly dramatically to our society. In fact, if you really want to check it, see who is still delivering meals on wheels. Mostly they are the elderly people in our society—active and fit and wanting to have a go. I think it is vitally important that we recognise that our policies deal with the frail elderly, particularly to support them being able to live out their lives at home, and particularly to support families to help with that care. That is exactly what those community aged care packages are for.

I was very interested to read in the Telegraph Mirror on 4 September about a new family policy of the opposition's called `empowering Australian families'. I can only wonder why the opposition policy has not been publicly released. What is this policy that the opposition is sitting on? Is it one step more than the hypothetical or is it something you are planning to dribble out?

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Has the minister received representations calling on the Australian government to review the comprehensive plan of action, which defines the process by which Indo-Chinese refugees make application to be approved to come to live in Australia? Is there evidence of significant bribery and corruption undermining the integrity of the CPA? What steps has the minister taken to achieve an independent audit of the actions of officers of the United Nations High Commission on Refugees and others involved in screening in or screening out those applicants from Vietnam and other countries in the refugee camps in South-East Asia? Finally, how has the minister responded to the damning conclusions of this year's United States of America congressional inquiry into the comprehensive plan of action?
—Senator Teague raises an issue here which has been current as a plan of action for some five years now—in fact, 1989 was the inception of the CPA.
—June.

—June—I think Senator Ray was there at the time. It is a plan of action to do a number of things; it was based on five fundamental principles. They were to focus on movements within the Indo-Chinese region; to discourage clandestine departures and to establish a regular program of departures; to institute regional refugee status determination procedures; to organise the resettlement of those who arrived in the first asylum camps before cut-off dates; and also to organise the return of non-refugees to their country of origin.

PARA.TAB: As a plan it has been enormously successful. In its time of operation some 80,000 people have been resettled in destinations other than Vietnam. In terms of Australia, we have taken some 18,500 Indo-Chinese under the CPA, with another 300 or so being resettled in this program year. As well as that 80,000, some 72,000 have returned to Vietnam, and there are now some 41,000 in camps—and they are the ones who, of course, have been screened out by the process.

From time to time concerns have been raised about the processing and whether, in fact, it has been an honest processing. We have tackled this issue in this parliament—in the Senate, in fact—a number of times and, as a government, I have raised the matter with the UNHCR on both the regional and international levels.

I can, Senator Teague, provide for you copies of the relevant correspondence and assurances we have had—assurances which I think were tabled in this place at the start of this year. The allegations that you refer to in the request for review are not those of the immediate past; they have been around for some time. They were issues which the Senate focused on at an earlier date some few months ago. I can make that information available to you again; it was, in fact, tabled in here.

We have been keen to ensure that the processes have been aboveboard. We have received from the UNHCR unequivocal assurances that no-one whom it has assessed as a genuine refugee has been screened out or returned to Vietnam. That is an assurance which is quite basic to the integrity of the process. As I say, when you look at the process involved here, you will see that the process is one that is administered by the countries of first asylum, and it is monitored closely by UNHCR. We have had assurances from them and, once again, whatever might be available I can make available to you.

In terms of the US situation, there is a bit of game playing going on in the US. That is very unfortunate because the member parties to the CPA have made a decision to essentially wind up the process by the end of this year and to return those who have been screened out and who are not entitled to refugee status to Vietnam by the end of this year.

Of course, with the takeover in the US Congress, there has been a different focus applied to the CPA from there. I think that offers false hope to the people in the camps—and that is the unfortunate aspect of it. —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. TALK.START.PARA: —The minister did not answer my question, which could have been answered with a yes and a yes, with a yes and a no, or with a no and a no. —Thank you very much, Senator Bourne, for the question. The article you refer to has been drawn to my attention. PARA.TAB: Broadly, the minister's advice to me is that the Telstra news corporation cable television venture announced on 9 March is something that he welcomes. He is aware, as I am now, of press speculation concerning the possibility of payments arising due to the commercial agreements that Telstra has entered into for pay television.

It is proceeding on the basis that this will be a profitable investment. This is part of the process of developing, as it is for the news group which has taken on the same liabilities for the same reasons. The minister is aware—and I am now aware—of Telstra's involvement in this venture, but undertakings of this nature are matters for consideration and decision by the Telstra board. I want to re-emphasise that Telstra Multi-Media Pty Ltd has entered into the overall arrangement and intends to charge for the use of the cable and expects to obtain a commercial rate of return on its investment. That is why it has entered into the arrangement. To the best of my advice, it is not an unusual or unorthodox commercial arrangement and it is one on which they expect to return a profit on the shareholders' funds, which are the Australian people's funds.

There is no coercion of course, but there is strong encouragement for doctors to enter into contracts of that sort. At the moment, with this legislation about to be passed, it is very disappointing that significant quarters of that same profession, the medical profession, are actively campaigning against doctors signing those contracts. As to any figures, I do not have those to give you. The start-up date of 1 October is a matter of concern. If so, how will you force them to sign the agreements in the next five days?

Secondly, if there is no change in the contracts and if no doctors enter into contracts, that will not make much difference at all. The system will continue as it is now. In other words, private health insurance will not be able to reassure patients that they have 100 per cent cover. Until the contracts with the doctors are entered into, very much the same system as is the case now will prevail. So there is no need and there should be no encouragement for anyone to scare people by saying, `This legislation may mean that you can't get to hospital, you can't get cover and so on.' It is a question of saying—
—The legislation will be a failure.
—Well Senator, how do we know? What can we force people to do in the next five days? One could conclude from that that Senator Knowles—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have said that there is no coercing under this legislation. It is vitally important that that is understood. (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Murdered Hostages: Freedom of Information Requests

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Gareth Evans, I want to give some more information concerning an answer he supplied yesterday to Senator Woods. In answering a question yesterday from Senator Woods on freedom of information applications by the families of Kellie Wilkinson and David Wilson, Senator Evans undertook to check the status of the consideration of these requests. As Senator Evans indicated yesterday, these FOI requests relate to extremely tragic affairs and involve complex matters involving many months of government activity, and a number of issues go to intergovernmental relations.

PARA.TAB: Both requests captured a vast amount of material, certainly many hundreds of documents in each case which have to be carefully assessed for release, and in many instances consultations have to be undertaken with other authorities and foreign governments involved in the cases. Senators will recall that in these tragic cases the Australian government worked closely with the British and French governments, which also had citizens involved, as well as the Cambodian government.

With respect to the Wilkinson application, which was received by the department on 27 February this year, 112 documents were released to the applicant on 25 May. A similar number of documents were identified as requiring consultations with other authorities and governments as to their suitability for release. Where material reporting on their views or actions was captured, consultation had to be undertaken with New Scotland Yard by the AFP, the British Foreign and Commonwealth Office, the US State Department, the Cambodian government, the United Nations Secretariat and the Office of the Governor-General.

All of this has taken some time. However, this process of consultation is close to completion and the departmental decision maker appointed under the act will shortly be making a decision on most of the remaining material and advising the applicant.

The FOI application from members of the Wilson family was received by the department on 15 June. The department in a letter to the applicants noted that this request was very complicated and would take some time to process. The departmental decision maker handling this request is now well advanced in his assessment of the material and it is anticipated that he will be writing to the applicants this week forwarding the first tranche of material for release.

While the department will be seeking to process material as quickly as possible, there is likely to be need in this case too for a number of consultations with other authorities and governments on the possible release of material which reports their views or actions. Documents are, therefore, likely to be released in tranches as the outcomes of consultations become known and are assessed by the decision maker.

Senator Evans and our department are committed to the principles of FOI and approach all applications with the disposition to release material wherever possible. This is the spirit in which the processing of these two FOI applications has been undertaken, notwithstanding their complexity and sensitivity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Short this day, relating to interest rates.

SPEECH.PARA: This relates to Senator Cook's inability to deny the point made in my question that, when the government's own rate of inflation calculation is taken into account, Australia's real interest rates, both short-term and long-term, are in fact amongst the highest in the world. In his answer, Senator Cook stuck with the assertion of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) yesterday that Australia's short term interest rates `are the seventh lowest in the OECD area' and that this was shown by statistics in the latest edition of the Economist magazine.

PARA.TAB: I assume that both the Prime Minister and Senator Cook are referring to real interest rates. I also assume that they are basing this assertion on a graph in the Economist showing nominal interest rates less the inflation rate. The only way that you can manipulate the figures to achieve the Prime Minister's result—and even if one accepts that result, it is a pretty middling result at best—is to use as the relevant inflation rate what is nowadays termed in Australia as the headline rate of inflation; that is, in effect, the ordinary consumer price index. For years now this government has been asserting that the headline rate of inflation is not the true rate of inflation.

The government has, instead, chosen to use what it calls the underlying rate of inflation. The underlying rate of inflation is the headline rate adjusted to take out movements in mortgage interest rates, taxes, charges and several other items that affect the headline rate. Using the underlying rate—this is, as I said, the government's own preferred rate—as the true inflation rate, the fact is that Australia's real interest rates are just about the highest in the Western world. As I said, real short-term rates are the third highest in the Western world, according to the Economist magazine. The real government bond yield, which is the rate which most influences our ongoing interest rate environment, is the second highest in the OECD area.

The government cannot have it both ways. It cannot on the one hand claim that our real interest rates are in the middle of the OECD field and at the same time claim that our inflation is amongst the lowest in the OECD. To claim the former is to say that the true inflation rate is the headline rate. That is the only way he can justify his former statement. That is a fact that today Senator Cook, as I understand it, actually eschewed; he backed away from that.

If the government wants to change its view on this point to accommodate the Prime Minister's interest rate assertion, then it has the acknowledge that far from Australia having a low inflation rate it in fact has the second highest inflation rate in the whole of the OECD, second only to Italy. I repeat: the government cannot have it both ways. It cannot claim that it has low inflation and that our real interest rate regime is in the middle of the pack. The two are fundamentally inconsistent. Yet the government has tried to mislead the Australian public for a long time now that we are doing well on the interest rate front and on the inflation rate front.

Even on the government's own manipulated figures, we are not doing that well on the interest rate front. To get that result, the government has to acknowledge that we have a serious inflation problem emerging. We have the second highest inflation rate in the industrialised world. That is an inflation rate that is higher than many of the other non-OECD countries which are among the fastest growing countries on earth and our major trading partners. That is undeniable, yet the government is very deliberately trying to mislead the Australian community on that very point.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Short just said, the government cannot have it both ways. Senator Short was asked to withdraw a statement which reflected upon the truthfulness of the answer of the Minister representing the Treasurer (Senator Cook). Quite frankly, the statement made by Senator Short may have been unparliamentary but it was absolutely spot on the target. Here you have a minister who is saying he has read the Economist magazine and is talking about how Australia is ranked in the middle in terms of inflation rates of OECD nations.

PARA.TAB: For the benefit of people who are listening to this or for the minister if he is tuning in, page 114 of this week's edition of the Economist lists the quarter inflation figures—that is, the three-month consumer price figure—and has Australia in equal first, equal pole position. David Beattie and Mick Doohan are on pole position for the grand prix of international inflation rates. Australia is right up there in pole position.

For annual inflation, we are just trailing Cadalora from Italy. Italy is on 5.8 per cent inflation; Australia is 4.5 per cent, and no-one else is even coming into the main straight. Australia is second place in the inflation rate stakes, yet this minister comes in representing the Treasurer in federal parliament and misleads the Australian people by saying we are in the middle of the field. You are not right, minister, and you are not right, Mr Treasurer. Australia has the second highest rate of inflation. That is why we are paying so much in our interest rates.

I just want to nail another one to the wall, if I can. This minister cannot resist coming in and repeating a lie about the comparison of both inflation and interest rates for the last coalition government, which concluded in March 1983, and the Hawke and Keating years. The facts are absolutely irrefutable—and I will seek to table this if the government will give me leave. Real interest rates under the Malcolm Fraser government were 4.08 per cent. The deflated real bank prime interest rate was 4.08 per cent.

In the Hawke and Keating years, when Mr Keating was pulling the economic levers, when he had the Reserve Bank in his pocket, the Treasury in his pocket, Finance in his pocket, and the international money market in his pocket—he must have had very big pockets in his Italian suit—what were the real prime bank interest rates? Not twice what they were under Mr Fraser and Mr Howard; they were more than double. The average real prime bank interest rate under this man as Prime Minister and Treasurer was 8.81 per cent—double the real rate.

You can fiddle around with base rates if you want but, because of the oil price shocks that Senator Short would remember from that time, inflation around the world was a lot higher. It was a massive international problem because of what was happening to oil and the prices that flowed on from that.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the problem here is self-induced.

—That is right; this is very much self-induced. Our massive foreign debt crisis has been induced by this government, induced by its failure to manage the economy properly. It is always spending more than it earns, always running deficits at a time when the economy is in recovery. Basic high school economics says that you run surpluses during recoveries and deficits during recessions. This government runs deficits during recessions and deficits during recoveries—really smart! But it is costing people across Australia.

PARA.TAB: You can have an argument about short-term rates and long-term rates but the reality is that most businesses pay close to the prime bank interest rate. Small businesses and large businesses across the nation are paying a premium above everyone else in the OECD world.

If you want to talk about middle ranking rates of real interest, back in 1976 and 1981, when you had sensible economic management in this country, Australia was ranked around about 10th in the OECD for real interest rates. Under Mr Keating's financial stewardship, if he dare use that term, we had the third real highest interest rates in 1986, and from 1991 right through to 1995 we have had the highest real bank rates. He cannot deny that. It is in the Economist every week and I invite him to read the whole magazine, not just one page.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

Those people, I believe, were rightfully granted refugee status here in this country, and I think the vast majority of them are making very gainful contributions to Australia's life.

I must express some disappointment about the actions that are taking place in the United States Congress at the moment, actions, as I understand it, from a small number of individual congressmen—I am repeating the minister's words—which are giving false hope to people who are currently vegetating in the camps in South-East Asia.

`Vegetating' has been a kind word for some of the camps and, as I said, I have visited most of them. In a place like Whitehead in Hong Kong, it is much worse than vegetating. In that concrete and razor-wire establishment known as Whitehead, the individuals are subject to quite a deal of violence. We have witnessed on our television screens in recent times in this country the riots that have taken place in the camps, where the forces of law and order have had to go in under the protection of tear gas to bring back order to the place. Quite a number of the detainees have been injured, and some people have even lost their lives in those conflicts. The guards who look after the camps have also been injured.

With the best will in the world, the congressmen who are pushing forward that bill in the United States Congress are giving those people in the camps, particularly in places like Whitehead, some false hope that they will be resettled in the United States or in some other part of the world. This is after these people have gone through independent assessment—in the case of Whitehead, by the Hong Kong authorities. It is all overseen by the United Nations High Commission for Refugees, a body and establishment which I hold in the highest regard—which is not to say that we have not had some arguments during the Senate committee hearings on similar types of matters we have had to look into in this country.

It is unfortunate that those people have been given this false hope and that some 40,000 people continue to vegetate in places like Galang Island and Sungei Besi in Whitehead when they should be back in their homeland rebuilding their lives. Whilst one congressional report has been mentioned, another United States initiative with the aid organisations who visited Vietnam and many of the camps came down with a much more positive report than the one that has been mentioned today by Senator Teague in his question to the minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Jacinta Collins this day, relating to aged care services and the home and community care program.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister's comments were nothing more than a pea and thimble trick, which we ought to become used to from this government in a number of areas. She talked about the community aged care places for older people as if they were additional aged care places, but they are not. I do not mind her getting up and saying what the government is doing but she really should tell the whole story—not half of it. That is what happened today in the chamber.

PARA.TAB: The government's planning ratios of 100 nursing home, hostel and community aged care package places per 1,000 people aged over 70 have not increased. They have simply been rejigged. We have seen this happen in lots of other areas as well, and here it is happening again. People listening to question time on the radio or from up in the galleries would have thought that these were new places for older people to keep them out of institutions and at home. They are not new places. They are the ratios rejigged. They are simply places that have been taken from the nursing home and hostel sectors so that in the future there will be 40 nursing beds, 50 hostel beds and 10 community aged care packages per 1,000 of the population aged over 70.

There are enormous problems in the aged care area. Many nursing homes are in a crisis situation because of a lack of adequate funding—just look at the planning ratios I just mentioned. These ratios need to be monitored carefully to ensure they are realistic and appropriate for Australia's ageing population. They were developed in the mid-1980s, when only 11 per cent of people aged 70 or over were over 85 years. By 2021, this figure will have increased to 16 per cent. So the supply of residential aged care places relative to the over-85 population will, in effect, decrease significantly over that period. It may be that the planning ratios will need to be adjusted in future to respond to changing circumstances.

Senator Crowley should have explained this in more detail when she answered that question. As I said, it appeared from what she said that these were new, you-beaut places. In fact, what we have is the same number of services for older people but in a different form. We are not saying that we should not have home and community care packages. There are some people who choose to be at home and who really need the level of care that you would get in residence at a nursing home, but they can stay at home with appropriate care. What we are saying, though, is that the government cannot have it both ways; it cannot pretend that this is something new.

The other problem that we have seen with the rigid planning ratios is that they are based on regions and they do not allow or reflect regional differences. For example, an area which attracts a large number of retirees may well develop, over time, a disproportionate number of people over 85, and they are the group that have a greater demand on nursing home places. If there is a disproportionate number of people over 85 in an area, there will be a greater demand for aged care services in that area.

With these ratios and in the concepts behind them there is an assumption that, as a proportion of the old, old increases, the supply of carers will continue to meet the demand for care in the community. Whether one likes it or not, the home aged care package does place some demands on the carers, who are usually women.

It may not be the case that we have the same number of carers in the community that we have today. We have higher labour market participation rates of women. It is also the fact that potential carers will be older themselves. As more people live into that 85-year-old category, their daughters and sons will be older themselves and maybe not in a position to care for their ageing parents, in their 80s and 90s. We see increasing numbers of remarriages and divorces and that entails complications as to who is responsible for parents and step-parents.

I will not go on about the shortfall in the funding required to upgrade nursing homes, which Professor Gregory outlined, or the government's failure to fund dementia-specific facilities—we have seen one close down in Melbourne just recently because the government has failed to subsidise that—or its continued failure to meet the needs of people with dementia for residential facilities. The minister's coming in here today, going on as if it was a new program, had to be shown for what it was; that is, a pea and thimble trick. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Wheelwright this day, relating to the promotion of science in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I just wish we had a minister for science who would put his brain into gear when he opened his mouth to start speaking. What we have is just words, words, words. We have economic diatribe as a substitute for real dialogue and discussion about where science is going in this country.

PARA.TAB: When the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) starts speaking about science, very quickly—within a sentence—he is talking about innovation, competition, economic growth, new industries and material advantage. The minister does not even understand what science is about. He is talking about technology and he is talking about technology linked with industry. There is a vast difference, which the minister simply does not understand. That came out very clearly in that diatribe with which he went on today.

When one looks at science as the basic and strategic foundation on which that innovation, competition and industrial development is based, one finds that Australia is in a declining position, not an improving position. We need to look, for instance, at the work that has been done over some years now in the Australian National University on the science citation index. This is a direct measure of the value scientists elsewhere in the world put on Australian science; that is, the number of times other scientists find the work done by Australian scientists worthy of being quoted when they do their own research work.

What one finds is that, particularly since 1987, there has been a very significant decline in the relative rate of science citation for Australian scientific publications. These are publications in the proper, refereed scientific journals. This is not explained by claims that what we are doing is patenting more work—that work is not appearing in the journals but that the work is nonetheless being down—because when one looks at other countries, at Japan and the US, one sees that, despite the higher rate of patenting in those countries, their relative science citation rate has either been maintained or in fact is increased.

When one looks at this basic element of science, one finds declining standards. One finds that the money the minister talked about is a confused hotchpotch of technology-industry money mixed up with science. The minister claims that that amount has been increased, but when one looks at the money going into basic science, one finds that that is not there and that scientists all over the country, whether in the CSIRO or the universities, are finding it extremely difficult.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't have one researcher on that side.

—No, I do not think they have. I do not think the minister would have a clue what science is all about. You find that university scientists are having larger and larger teaching loads. You find that they are having to spend large amounts of their time filling out forms, getting money from outside the university to support their research because there is not enough public funding for that sort of research. You find that they are then having to go out and patent things to try to get work.

PARA.TAB: One of my very good friends who works at the ANU and who has worked on plant hormones for years—decades, in fact—has now had to patent and try to promote a chemical lawn-mower. That might be a good idea, but I think it is terrible that a person of great ability is having to do that sort of thing instead of devoting himself to the excellent and consistent work which he has done over many years on plant hormones.

From the program last night on pilchards, one finds that there has been a run-down in AQIS, a run-down in the basic data which would allow us to protect this country from the importation of diseases. One finds it in the greenhouse area. One finds that the government does not even take any notice of the scientific advice it is getting. It believes that clean coal technology is somehow going to address the greenhouse problem.

The government is monumentally ignorant on this question of science—and it is not helped by the sorts of nonsense we heard from the minister today on this question. The minister simply does not understand; the minister is confused. I take Senator Patterson's point: I doubt whether the government could find anybody else to fill the role because they just do not have anybody.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—The Deputy President has received a letter from Senator Gibson proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

That as a result of the Keating Government's disastrous mismanagement of the economy, as evidenced by massive foreign and domestic debt, Australians have been forced to pay unnecessarily high interest rates on all borrowings, including home mortgages.

PROCTEXT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that informal arrangements have been made to allocate specific times to the speakers in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the clerks to set the clocks accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As all Australians would probably now be aware, there is a debate up and running in this country as to the consequences on our interest rates of the level of our foreign debt. Some may regard this as a theoretical debate, something to be left to university professors. Like other economic arguments, such as the appropriate level of tariffs, the current account debate and the effect on employment of higher inflation, there are clearly a number of schools of thinking.

PARA.TAB: To the ordinary Australian in the street this debate may seem to be an inordinate waste of good time, energy and breath. Why then would the Prime Minister of this nation devote an entire three-quarters of a page in the middle of a national newspaper to argue that his critics are wrong and that he is right on this subject? Why is it that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has decided that convincing Australians that he is right on this academic argument is critical to the future well-being of Australia—more important than unemployment, our current account deficit or even the health of our nation's kids? Why does he need to go into print on this topic and no other?

Perhaps one could cynically suggest that the Prime Minister has always been interested in this theoretical field and simply wants to demonstrate his standing. Perhaps he believes that there is merit in academic and theoretical truth, which warrants his intervention at this time. To suggest such propositions would require that one was not merely cynical but benignly stupid, given that the standing of the Prime Minister as an economic academic would be somewhere near absolute zero were it to be measured on a temperature scale.

It is true that Prime Minister Keating has used Australia as his economic laboratory. He has experimented on the Australian people with his theories and predilections, but on this occasion academic righteousness is not, sadly, the motivating factor urging the Prime Minister. Instead we see again the actions and reactions of the political animal—caged, attacked and taunted by an honest and obvious truth that he knows can damage his career, his job and his political neck. So he reacts. First, the attack on those who dare confront him with this truth. Challenge their credibility, their motives and their integrity—anything but their arguments. Call them sour and spiteful, ridicule and mock—play the man, but never the ball.

Secondly, call forth your true supporters to muddy the waters, stir up the debate, develop convoluted red herrings—anything to distract attention from the truth. Finally, when all else fails, call in a favour or two. Take a spot in the national daily in a most prominent position, have your staff prepare a discourse and lecture one and all from the high altar of the Prime Minister's office. But whatever else happens, avoid the homely, uncontestable truth.

What is the truth that the Prime Minister wants so desperately to avoid? It can be summarised with three facts: firstly, since the election of the Labor government in 1983 Australia's foreign debt has increased from $23 billion to a massive $180 billion; secondly, since the takeover of the prime ministership by Paul Keating in December 1991, the Commonwealth's own purpose debt has increased a staggering $70 billion to approach $100 billion; and, thirdly, as the Governor of the Reserve Bank was so delighted to concede yesterday:

SPEECH.PARA: Everyone should know that in economics everything is connected to everything else, so obviously in that sense debt has some connection with interest rates.

Debt has some connection with interest rates. It is, in the words of the Prime Minister's mate the Governor of the Reserve Bank, obvious. It is certainly obvious to all those paying interest on their loans. It is obvious to every business that tries to raise funds to keep their business afloat. It is obvious to every householder who borrows money to fund a home extension, a holiday or even the purchase of the bare essentials. It is obvious to everyone except a Prime Minister and a Labor Party that does not want the people of Australia to reflect on who has made possible Australia's appalling debt situation. Who is it that has created the need for Australian companies, not to mention Australian governments, to borrow overseas? It is the man who claimed he pulled the levers of the Australian economy—the man who has run this nation for 12 years. Prime Minister Keating made the claim, so he must take the blame.

PARA.TAB: Before the Labor Party senators opposite jump to their feet to recite the other words of wisdom from the Governor of the Reserve Bank, particularly his comments that those asserting a link between foreign debt and short-term interest rates were drawing a long bow, allow me to develop the question of the link a little further. On 30 March this year, in a speech to business economists, the governor said this:

SPEECH.PARA: So long as we remain so dependent on foreign savings, for which we must compete in international capital markets, we remain vulnerable to adverse swings in market sentiment.
Further he said:
The most obvious vulnerability is our exposure to a sharply falling exchange rate.
Further:
Downward pressure on the exchange rate, if it were to persist, would add to inflationary pressures and force the authorities into tough policy measures.

For those Labor senators opposite whose only understanding of economics is obtained by watching re-runs of The New Price is Right, I will explain it in simple language. The Keating Labor government has been chalking up debts for Australia—up to $70 billion over the past three years alone. To borrow that money it has gone into both the domestic market and, to a limited degree, the foreign market. When the federal government borrows money in Australia, it makes it harder for others to borrow in this country. As a consequence, the private sector and state governments look overseas to borrow money for investment purposes. That, in turn, pushes up our foreign debt, the amount we owe to the rest of the world. As the debt gets bigger, the greater is our risk. Companies can go broke and even states under Labor administrations can go close.

The key variable driving our current account deficit is not so much the cyclical trade balance, but the underlying income deficit; that is, the interest we are paying on our foreign debt and the profits we have to repatriate to foreign investors. That is the reason we think that our current account deficit will not be brought under control, even as our trade performance improves. There is now no test of whether an investment will provide a net economic benefit to Australia. There is now no opportunities test of whether a comparable Australian bidder is available. There is no transparency in decision making. There is no government response to the Senate print media inquiry report handed down nearly five months ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's coming. It's not far away. I promise that.
