The Economist magazine recently showed that Australia's bank prime interest rates are the highest among the 15 major industrialised countries.

As an aside, the Prime Minister's personal attitude to the economic worries of the average voters is worth noting. He is completely oblivious to the problems that people on the ground are facing. He is ensconced here in Canberra in the interest free home, the Lodge, and in his $2 million house in Woollahra in Sydney and has no concept whatever of how hard it is for the average home buyer.

The Prime Minister's rhetoric—`Voters have never had it so good' and `What are they complaining about?'—belies his total disdain for the rest of the country. Median house prices compiled by the Real Estate Institute of Australia show that house prices have remained static since the rises in interest rates began last year. This has happened simultaneously with home buyers suffering from comparatively high interest rates.

After enduring the `recession we had to have', home buyers are uncertain and frightened about their economic futures. The latest Westpac-Melbourne Institute survey finds that households are becoming more pessimistic about both the immediate and long-term economic outlook. Those who have bought houses and are feeling the pain of high interest rates are being told by the Prime Minister to save more.
A recent Financial Review article quoted the Prime Minister's address to the Collingwood Football Club, in which he had the hypocritical audacity to talk about the necessity of savings. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We inculcated a whole generation of Australians: buy a flat, buy a beach house, buy anything but basically don't save.
However, as Mr Bernie Fraser—who seems to feature in economic pronouncements these days—said in a speech to Australian business economists in March this year:
. . . the greatest scope exists to boost national saving—through the reduction and elimination of budget deficits.
What is the government doing to achieve that? Absolutely nothing. Perhaps the Treasurer, Mr Willis, does not read his own budget papers, in which he said this year:
. . . a high level of foreign debt borrowing relative to GDP can impose costs on an economy by making it vulnerable to external shocks and by raising interest rate premia on borrowings.
How else could Mr Willis have categorically denied, as he did last week, any link between mortgage interest rates and foreign debt?

PARA.TAB: The words used by Tom Valentine, the Dean of Commerce at the University of Western Sydney, have already been used by Senator Minchin and illustrate this argument very well. I suspect the Prime Minister knows it too. I quote again from Laura Tingle's article in the Australian of 23 September, where she said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . at the height of the interest rate pain in 1989, Keating justified using high interest rates because they had the benefit of sharing the pain of attacking Australia's trade and debt problems, which spending cuts did not . . . `Monetary policy gives you a reduction [in living standards] across the board so the yuppies are paying too!' he said.
That is the Prime Minister gloating over the pain that his government has caused.

PARA.TAB: Australians at every level are experiencing painful financial times because the Prime Minister is running that sort of economic debate. The fact remains that if we continue to choose to grow at a rate faster than we can finance—that is ultimately a decision for the government of the day—we have to borrow more to do it. The Prime Minister should look at his own record.

And what of the future? The present import figures and the disconcerting outlook on inflation, as outlined by my colleagues in the very knowledgeable economic argument they have run, mean that we are left with possibly more of the same in the future. There is no relief in sight. The ultimate indictment of this government is that they have disastrously mismanaged the economy, we have massive foreign and domestic debt, and we are now paying unnecessarily high interest rates. As quoted in the Australian of 23 September, the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is very much akin to a domestic household—you don't have enough savings yourself to buy your first home so you borrow . . .
If we all adopted that strategy we would be in very parlous economic circumstances.

PARA.TAB: According to Mr Keating, we should borrow from the rest of the world to build a stronger Australian economy. But we cannot continue at this rate. The level of debt, both foreign and domestic, is absolutely appalling. I feel sure that Australians will be hoping for a change in government so that we can reverse this disastrous state of affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is one of those issues we see in a run-up to an election where there is an attempt to confuse and divide and to somehow or other take attention away from the fact that Liberal Party policy in these areas is really about undermining the living conditions of the Australian people. This exercise is a sort of re-run of what we saw in Victoria.

PARA.TAB: I am very familiar with Liberal Party tactics, with their lorry of lies and all their other great billboard posters that we saw around Melbourne at the last election. But the lorry of lies has broken down today. The whole exercise, the whole device has broken down and their exposure is all too apparent.

TALK.START.PARA: —The clutch is gone.

—Yes, because they have been riding it far too hard. Today we have seen yet another attempt to confuse and divide. The present situation with respect to debt in Australia should be stated clearly, and that is that 60 per cent of our debt is private sector debt. Of the 40 per cent from the public sector broadly defined, only four per cent can be attributed directly to the Commonwealth government, and it has not been borrowing since the late 1980s.

PARA.TAB: We have seen those opposite attempt to present the figures as showing that Australians individually have a $10,000 debt. When we point to the World Bank survey that shows that $1.1 million in assets could equally be attributed to individual Australians, they say that is a load of nonsense.

What is the Liberal Party proposing to do about the position? What have we heard on that question? Their options, essentially, are these: they either have to find a monetary policy—as far as I am concerned, changes in economic policy would ultimately lead to higher interest rates—or they have to present a policy on the social wage which would fundamentally undermine the living conditions of ordinary Australians.

You are saying that the Australian government has to reduce its outlays and that it is crowding out the private sector by calling upon the savings of Australians for its budgetary policies. You then say that the budget has to be cut. That is clearly your policy. That is what you are saying.

TALK.START.PARA: —To stop wasting money.

—I take that interjection. You are basically saying that the budget has to be cut. You are saying that Australians should understand that the $7,000 per individual that the government provides every year by way of its social wage contribution—for education, health, social security welfare, housing and community payments—should be directed instead to reducing the foreign debt. That is where your argument leads. You are saying that the living standards of ordinary Australians have to be cut.

PARA.TAB: Of course, with respect to the aggregate capital stock that is available to this country, with respect to the growth of the economy and productive investment in this country, you do not say anything. You do not say anything about controlling the level of foreign investment. You are saying that the social wage of Australians has to be reduced. Ultimately, that is the political hypocrisy of your position. You are saying that interest rates are the key when you really mean that budgets have to be cut, the size of government reduced and the living standards of Australians reduced accordingly. That is Liberal Party policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday we debated debt and interest rates. Today we are debating debt and interest rates, this time in relation to housing. When the government started putting up interest rates to counteract the bad current account deficit a few months ago we said that it would not work as a savings mechanism. It hasn't.

PARA.TAB: Incidentally, we also said that the compulsory superannuation scheme to increase savings is not an answer to our current account deficit problem, even if it could be made more equitable than the government intends. Today the Financial Review reports that the Reserve Bank agrees with us. But the focus of this debate seems to be the impact of interest rates on house mortgages.

When interest rates went up earlier this year we pointed out that this would increase the cost of mortgages, reducing family disposable income. Among other things, this reduces family savings and is therefore counterproductive. It may increase bank profits but such profits are driving expansion of banks with the purchase or establishment of banks in the United States, Indonesia and other countries. It is part of the flight of capital from Australia.

We also mentioned that increased interest rates were likely to raise costs for small business in a variety of ways at a time when they had little option to increase prices. That will probably be the subject of an MPI later this week.

Increases in interest rates often affect home mortgages. Servicing the average mortgage is the single most significant monthly expenditure for most people. Home mortgage servicing costs are often 50 per cent or more of a family's weekly post-tax earnings, and a change of a few per cent can have significant impact on disposable income remaining after the mortgage is paid.

Another thing for many people is that the value of their homes are currently declining while interest rates are rising. People are in the invidious position where, if they sell their home, they have less money than when they began, and many are even in debt after their home sale.

Our urban planning and housing policies affect prices. In boom times in the housing market or when government proposes to freeze land releases or building approvals, as the ACT government has just done, home prices rise in a way unrelated to underlying values. Foreign house purchases also introduce factors external to our economy, which is why you can have a boom cycle and lower housing prices or a huge increase in prices when there is not much happening in the economy.

The urban planning issues can be seen where areas of decreasing home values are generally in the poorer, usually outlying, suburbs. Trendy inner city house prices continue to rise. This is the impact of the inability to buy due to low wage levels, coupled with urban planning that makes these areas undesirable. Old inner city working-class areas, with their proximity to services and low transport needs, are the new abode of the diminishing middle class.

The dispersed areas of public housing, semi-public housing and cheap housing continue to generate negative equity. The areas are expensive to live in, although they are cheaper to buy. It is mainly initial low cost and the existence of public sector loan assistance that drives the poorer people to buy in these areas. Their purchase often has more to do with waiting lists and availability of loans than the state of the market, so they can get caught out. Efforts to raise prices by freezing development simply distort prices and further reduce the market, since it becomes more difficult for people wanting to buy as residents to purchase a home. It must be seen that there are elements, as I have mentioned before, in our housing markets which impact on people's payments much more than interest rates, though interest rates are important.

All in all, these kinds of issues appear to have been missed by both of the major parties. The cost of housing ought to be considered in many areas of public policy. So far, the debate has been very limited. It is about interest rates, yes; it is about availability of housing; it is about the way we design our cities; it is about affordability of housing; and it is about time we integrated the policies so that people could have the right to affordable housing.

DEBATE.TITLE: STUDENT AND YOUTH ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT (YOUTH TRAINING ALLOWANCE) BILL 1995

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —According to the running sheet, the coalition's amendment comes next. As I understand it, it was suggested that amendments to clause 2 be left until last. But, in any event, I am not minded to press our amendment to clause 2, which was the first amendment that appeared on the request for amendments under my name, as has been circulated in the chamber.

PARA.TAB: The one I wanted to move was the second amendment on that sheet, which would introduce a concession to the parental assets test. It is in the terms that we debated in some detail in the chamber last night—incidentally, because we were dealing with another matter. This was an alternative to that other matter, and it is to provide some respite to families where they have obtained a health care card as a result of low income. We propose that, if they obtain such a card because of low income, they should not have to also meet an assets test in order to obtain Austudy for their children.

Basically, it is to provide some further benefit for those who have suffered as a result of the drought—which was the subject of much debate in here last night—or for other reasons; it could be in the country or in the towns. Certainly, in the case of the country, it could be not only primary producers, which the Democrats were seeking to benefit last night, but also those in towns. If they find that their income has fallen below the threshold but yet their asset base has remained reasonably high—although they are not often in a position where they can get any material benefit from that reasonably high assets base—we say that their children should not be disadvantaged in education. That is basically the argument for the amendment we put.

I remind you, Mr Chairman, that we have moved this amendment on previous occasions—in fact, successfully—and regrettably it has not been picked up by the government. I say `regrettably' because the government had, at an earlier stage, promised that it would meet this request. We are surprised that the government cannot see this concern of families who have been suffering from the plight of low income but nevertheless failing to obtain Austudy because of a reasonably high assets base.

We cannot see any reason why their children should suffer and be disadvantaged in education as a result of that. We are anxious to provide equity within education in Australia for students. We do not think that occurs at the moment, particularly in relation to rural students, particularly in circumstances beyond the control of the rural community and the rural town community in times of extraordinary drought, as we have been experiencing in this country, and in times of adverse changes in commodity prices and the like.

We will be moving the amendment again with the hope that it will be picked up by the government and that rural children can gain some benefit from that. I hope the Australian Democrats will support us. I hope on this occasion, which will be, as I said, the first occasion, the government will finally recognise the merit of this proposal and give rural kids a chance. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.After Schedule 1, page 4, insert the following schedule:

PARA.TAB: Section 3

SPEECH.PARA: "CONCESSION TO PARENTAL ASSETS TEST
"1. After section 7 in Part 2:

TAB.TAB: Insert:

SPEECH.PARA: '8.In determining what benefit is payable under this Part, a parental assets test is not to be applied in the calculation of a student's living allowance if the parent is entitled to a Health Care Card issued by the Department of Social Security for the purposes of the National Health Act 1953.'.".

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate to the chamber that the Australian Democrats will be supporting this second-best amendment. I draw the chamber's attention to the debate when we had before us both this amendment and the amendment that was defeated last night by the combined vote of the government and the opposition. The Democrats indicated then that the best option would have been to have supported both amendments because they do not cover the same group of people, as the opposition has now learned. Those amendments cover two different groups of people, and we would have had the best of both worlds. Unfortunately, the opposition could not see its way clear to supporting our amendment. I am disappointed about that.

PARA.TAB: I want to comment today on something Senator Hill said last night which is relevant to this debate, and that is his plea that the Democrats should give the government a serve and not pick on the Liberal Party all the time. I wanted to respond to that by saying that last night we were indeed picking on the Liberal Party and making an appeal to the National Party, because we were able to distinguish between the two in terms of their real commitment.

I agree with Senator Hill that the government needs just as big a stick applied to it as he felt we were applying to the Liberal Party because the government has, as Senator Hill indicated, turned down on every occasion the opportunity to help Australian kids within farming families and within country areas to get the kind of justice and education they need to equip them for the kind of future which we all believe young people in Australia ought to have.

I say to Senator Hill that, if I were a little harsh in my criticism of the opposition, that criticism certainly goes to the government. As Senator Hill pointed out, it is the government which has rejected not only the Democrats' amendment but also the amendment moved by the opposition last time and supported by the Democrats—which was to eliminate the assets test for Austudy for those people who had a health care card.

The Democrats are prepared to support this amendment because we believe it will help some people. It will not help as many people as would have been helped by our amendment, but nevertheless we are prepared certainly to do that much and to vote for this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to be able to support Senator Hill's amendment. The rural community, primary industry and their families owe a great deal of thanks to you, Senator Hill, for running with this amendment. As for it being a second-best amendment, there is a lot to be said for both amendments. The amendment that we have moved does not distinguish between farm families and small business that are affected by the drought. People out there are all in the same boat, or the same town, together. If primary industry and the farmers are doing it tough, that will be reflected on the business community that are also suffering.

PARA.TAB: The amendment that Senator Hill has put forward to the committee will pick up the small business people in the towns who would, I believe, have a negative income or a very minor income at the moment. They are suffering equally as hard as the people on the farm. There is a lot to be said for our amendment, and I am very glad that it is going to go through. I see Senator Margetts is in the chamber. I feel sure that she is going to support this amendment. The government will be defeated, as they rightly should.

I have said in this chamber on a number of occasions that every child in Australia deserves the right to participate in education. Many children in rural Australia at the moment are being tricked out of a tertiary education because the assets of their parents are worth over $750,000. Many primary industry properties—properties, farms, grazing properties—have assets worth over $750,000 but have not had an income for the last four or five years.

That has been picked up, and I concede that has been picked up, in the drought relief package that has been released and has benefited most Queenslanders, many farmers from New South Wales, although not all, very few from Victoria but none from South Australia. There are a huge number of people there who literally cannot afford to send their children to school or to tertiary education. Either amendment—the Woodley amendment or the Hill amendment—will be able to facilitate an education for the sons and daughters of Australian farmers. So we are really splitting hairs over the issue.

Senator Woodley has contacted, either by ringing or writing, most primary industry representatives, such as the Cattlemen's Union, the UGA and the sugar industry, asking them to lend support to his amendment. I have received representations from all those people, and I have rung back most of them and said that this health care card amendment will do the job. They have been grateful and, in a lot of cases, they have said that it will do the job. In most cases they say, `We are very grateful that we will be able to get that. As long as you will hold the line and the Senate will hold the line on that health care card, we are happy.'

Senator Hill's point yesterday was a very good point: we have to make the government stick to this amendment. On four occasions the minister has allowed papers and documentation—they may not have been from the minister and they may not have been in the budget papers, but DEET is a government department and the minister is responsible for his department—to go out that have built up expectations amongst country children that they could access tertiary education if their parents' income was under $20,000 only to have it cruelly snatched away two or three months later.

It is the government that should get the stick on this piece of legislation. It is the government that has rejected tertiary education for many children. I am very grateful that Senator Hill has moved this amendment. I know that everyone in the Senate, apart from the Labor Party, which, for some reason, hates farmers, is going to support the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, I asked a question of the duty minister, Senator Sherry, about the way assets were handled under the health care card.
—Senator Crowley is not listening to you.

—I know that Senator Crowley is not listening to me. The answer was not given yesterday. What we were given was a list of those people whose assets were not calculated, who were exempt from the calculation of assets under the health care card. I would like to re-ask the question. It is a pity the answer was not given yesterday, because we were faced with the prospect of supporting one amendment or the other. It would have been extremely useful if the minister had answered the question as asked so that we would know clearly the difference, if there was one, between the amendments in terms of impact.

PARA.TAB: I re-ask the question about how assets are handled under the national health care card. I do not want, as we got yesterday, a list of those people who did not have to have their assets calculated. We want to get an idea of the treatment of assets and whether or not this will impact on the rural community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts, I am still not sure what your question is. Could I just ask you to run it again? You do not want a list of the people who get a health care card but do not have to have an assets test, or do you? Could you make it more specific as to what information you are looking for?

—What I asked for yesterday was a summary of the treatment of assets in relation to a health care card. What I got yesterday was simply a list of those people and categories for whom assets were not calculated. What I was after was a general thumbnail sketch of the treatment of assets under a health care card so that we could get an idea of how this amendment might impact on the rural community. That is, which people do or do not get a health care card in relation to their assets?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will do my best. The majority of health care card recipients are families who are assets tested to be eligible for Commonwealth benefits, such as jobsearch or additional family payments. The majority of health care card recipients are already assets tested. The health care card is also, though, issued to some low income earners who do not need to meet an assets test. That is a relatively small group, and it is, in particular, to make sure that people who have a low income are assisted for the purposes of the benefits of the health care card. They are a much smaller group than the health care card assets tested recipients, but not so small as to mean that if this amendment passes there will not be a cost to government.

PARA.TAB: I am advised that that cost to government, if all health care card recipients become eligible, would be some $10 million or more. It is true that some of the people who are eligible for a health care card as low income people are those who have actually arranged their finances and so on to be asset rich and income poor. So the concern is to make sure that, while they are assisted as low income people for the benefits of a health care card, they are not also further benefited under this legislation for Austudy.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not suggesting that farmers have so arranged their assets, are you?

—That interjection from Senator Hill probably does deserve a comment. Am I suggesting they are farmers? No. I am not making any suggestion about who they are. There are certainly examples of people from a number of quarters who are able to arrange their assets and incomes so as to be beneficiaries of this sort, but it is not a question of debating this at length. We have been through it. I think this was canvassed very extensively yesterday. I think the understanding is quite clear that what the opposition and the Democrats are doing is placing great concern on ensuring that rural families are not disadvantaged in providing educational opportunities for their children. I do not think there is any dispute about that at all.

PARA.TAB: The government is also concerned that, as a matter of equity, the people applying for Austudy are treated in the same manner as much as possible. The extension of your amendment to health care card recipients who are not assets tested would certainly provide a potential for inequity there as well as, of course, an increase in outlays. The government is not minded to support the amendment that you are moving, Senator Hill. Senator Margetts, does that answer your question?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am actually trying to get a picture of how such things as the family farm are handled as assets under the health care card because those are the people the opposition is aiming at here, I presume.
—I am advised that there is some difference in the assets test depending on which payment a person is applying for. Senator Margetts, can I take that on notice and get back to you?
—Yes.

PARA.TAB: Request agreed to.
Schedule 3.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some brief comments about schedule 3. These comments also apply to schedule 4, although I realise that we are dealing with those separately. My making the comments on both schedules together will save some time. My brief comments relate to schedules 3 and 4 as they both relate to the way in which the department will treat compensation payments received by youth training allowance recipients.

PARA.TAB: At the moment, for ease of administration the department assumes that where any loss of income component can be identified in a compensation payment, 50 per cent of that payment has been made for loss of income. The department then divides this amount by average weekly earnings to calculate the number of weeks a person is precluded from their payment. I have said before in this place that I do not fully support the use of this 50 per cent rule. The impact of this rule on a person who only receives 25 per cent of his or her compensation payment for economic loss, and the rest to cover medical expenses, must be devastating.

While the Democrats recognise the problem of payment construction—that is, artificial construction—designed to disguise the true nature of a compensation payment, our position has always been that we could not support proposals to address this problem which would disadvantage many compensation recipients.

We believe that the amendments before us today will adversely affect compensation recipients and, as such, we will not be supporting them. The Democrats are also opposed to the amendments which will apply the compensation provisions to payment claimants as well as recipients. For these reasons, the Democrats will be opposing schedules 3 and 4.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been asked to accept that two or more lump sum payments be treated as one sum. Welfare rights groups argue that the payments should not be looked on as economic payments but as payments to help the person involved adjust—such as in modifying their home, et cetera. The government, however, sees a percentage of the payment as income and as a possibility of saving them money on pensions.

PARA.TAB: The government's position I do not believe is supportable for two reasons. Firstly, they have not provided us with figures to show how many cases or how much money is involved. Secondly, properly trained staff could pick out the odd questionable case where compensation is really for income and not for pain and suffering. So it seems as though we are looking for a way of further adjusting the bottom line for people who are on the lowest levels of income, and those who are requiring compensation for proper reasons will be the ones who will be affected.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The set of amendments moved by Senator Woodley proposes to delete various provisions that have recently been considered by the Senate. Identical provisions to these were contained in the social security legislation which was debated just a couple of weeks ago. They were amendments made to the provisions of the Social Security Act dealing with the jobsearch allowance. As the youth training allowance and the jobsearch allowance are closely aligned, it is important that any changes to jobsearch allowance be mirrored in the youth training allowance provisions of this Act.

PARA.TAB: Some amendments to the jobsearch allowance scheme contained in the social security legislation were rejected by this chamber. In recognition of this, the government is proposing amendments to this bill removing from it those elements of the jobsearch provision not passed by the Senate. In other words, when we come to government amendments, we will be moving to make sure that the two are in sync. For the reasons put during the previous debate, the government is not supporting any of Senator Woodley's proposed amendments.
Schedule agreed to.
Schedule 4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2)Schedule 4, page 10, omit items 1 to 6 inclusive, substitute:

PARA.TAB: "1. Paragraph 227(1)(a):

TAB.TAB: Before `is receiving' insert `claims or'.

SPEECH.PARA: Note: The heading to subsection 227(1) is altered by inserting `claiming or' after `Person'.

PARA.TAB: "2. Subsection 227(2):

SPEECH.PARA: Essentially, this raft of amendments does in schedule 4 what I have just said with schedule 3: it makes sure that there is consistency and sync between the social security provisions and the youth assistance.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Schedule 4, compensation recovery, changes the word qualification to `claims or receiving'. We are opposing this because it will mean that youth training allowance recipients will not be able to collect money while they are appealing, because they will not necessarily be already receiving although they will be qualified to receive. So, once again, we think this is eating away at the rights of people who can often ill afford to have their rights pulled away from them.

PARA.TAB: Schedule, as amended, agreed to.
Schedule 5.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak again to schedules 5 and 6, although I realise that of course we are dealing with them separately. Schedules 5 and 6 of this bill relate to the distinction between when a person ceases to qualify for a payment and when that person's payability ceases.

PARA.TAB: As I said to this provision in the social security bill we debated a few weeks back, the Democrats believe that the safeguards provided in the current system need to be maintained. We believe that passing this provision would be putting the onus on clients not only to inform the department of any changes in their circumstances but also to ensure that the department acts on that information in a timely fashion. That is a crazy proposition. The Democrats will not be supporting schedules 5 and 6.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens also will not be supporting schedules 5 and 6. We think if you lose a payment because of a breach of some kind, you just do not get cut off the youth training allowance but any other allowance as well. We oppose this because, if a person's qualifications are not worked out, their payments will be delayed or they will miss out on benefits. So we do not think there is much to support this particular debt recovery scheme.

PARA.TAB: Schedule agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes items 1 to 6 of schedule 6.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3)Schedule 6, page 18, heading to the Schedule, omit "AMENDMENTS", substitute "AMENDMENT".
This amendment changes the heading of schedule 6, consequent upon the omission of items 1 to 6.

PARA.TAB: Schedule 6, as amended, agreed to.
Schedule 7.

TALK.START.PARA: —Schedule 7 relates to the disclosure of information. Instead of being between department secretary and department secretary, this may involve a permanent delegation to underlings in a department and imposes no limits on the people who might be involved. Basically, it may well mean the permanent removal of many rights of people to get a fair hearing in a number of cases. Therefore, we oppose this amendment.

PARA.TAB: Schedule negatived.
Schedule 8.

TALK.START.PARA: —Schedule 8 of the bill provides that the decisions of a minister to disregard certain money held or loans for the purposes of the income test will not be reviewable decisions. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee said that `fairness demands, where an individual seeks the favour or exercise of what is so obviously a discretion, that review on the merits be available'. The Democrats will not be supporting schedule 8.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2), which proposes a range of amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1987. These proposals are largely non-controversial. Mr Acting Deputy President Herron, it is apt that you are in the chair because the main purpose of this bill is to remove customs duty from all imports of tobacco leaf, unmanufactured tobacco and tobacco products. At present, excise is payable on locally manufactured tobacco products and it is based on the weight of the product. There is another bill coming forward which will result in excise duty being applied to manufactured tobacco products from overseas.

PARA.TAB: The Industry Commission report No. 39, which reported into the tobacco growing and manufacturing industries, advised that the tobacco products industry existed in an artificial environment created by the protectionist measures of the tobacco industry stabilisation program and the local leaf content scheme. These economic buffer instruments have distorted the industry by insulating it from the dynamics of international tobacco trade.

To be fair, one has to cast one's mind back 20 or 30 years when there was a very good reason for the implementation of these schemes. In those days, tobacco smoking was not on the nose—if you can excuse the pun. In fact, 20 or 30 years ago it was considered to be a very socially acceptable habit. As a result of that, there was concern among governments of the day about the increase in the volume of imports of manufactured tobacco products. The government then moved to encourage growers to develop tobacco plants in Australia so that our balance of payments would not be adversely affected with the passage of time. However, times do change.

The Industry Commission report prompted a government response. On 13 November 1994, the government announced a tobacco industry restructuring package. The package was generally accepted by the tobacco industry. There were some complaints from pockets within the industry, but it was generally accepted—certainly in my own state of Queensland and also by the cigarette manufacturers. It constituted a deal between the industry, the state governments and the manufacturers, as I mentioned. Out of this negotiation, the cigarette manufacturers are to make a contribution of $10.8 million to the tobacco growing industry. Each of the tobacco growing states—Queensland, Victoria and New South Wales—is contributing $5.8 million, $850,000 and $3 million respectively to restructure the industry. This contribution will match the assistance of the cigarette manufacturers.

The Australian cigarette manufacturers will establish long-term contracts commercially negotiated between themselves and the individual local growers. The Commonwealth and the three tobacco producing states will not oppose any new or additional taxes on tobacco products. The Commonwealth will introduce an ad valorem 25 per cent tariff to be phased out in accordance with the World Trade Organisation agreement on all imports of tobacco leaf to establish a suitable adjustment period for growers of tobacco to evolve into the open international market. The quid pro quo for these contributions would be the removal of the protectionist instruments mentioned earlier, thus exposing the growers to international competition.

The termination of the local leaf content scheme and the tobacco industry stabilisation program, along with the introduction of the commission's other proposals, is in accordance with Australia's obligations under the Uruguay Round agricultural package, which decrees that all signatories convert all non-tariff trade barriers to tariff only assistance in order that all trade barriers are transparent to international scrutiny.

The review of the Australian Customs Service acknowledged the apparent anomaly argued by the Australian Medical Association between the government's policies of discouraging smoking and the government exempting tobacco products from duty. The Industry Commission report on the tobacco industry argues that, by removing trade barriers such as the local leaf content scheme and the tobacco industry stabilisation program in conjunction with the phasing out of tariff only assistance in accordance with the Uruguay Round agreements, the domestic tobacco industry would contract following exposure to the competition on the international tobacco market.

This amendment to remove the duty is a sound measure. It is one that was worked out well with the industry. It implements a successful negotiation between the industry and the state governments. It is a program designed to make our industry more competitive and our long-term use of government revenue more efficient.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995. The bill makes a number of amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1987. The first major measure, set out in clause 4 of the bill, will provide for the duty-free entry of certified reference materials. Reference materials are compounds with accurately known compositions which are used as a standard against which similar materials and processes can be compared and apparatus calibrated. By providing for the duty-free importation of certified reference materials, the amendment will allow for their wider use in industry and will provide cheaper inputs for the manufacturing sector. The Democrats will be supporting this part of the bill.

PARA.TAB: The second measure is a response to a recent AAT decision that determined that blankets containing viscose rayon in quantities varying from 81 per cent to 94 per cent were wholly of viscose. This had the effect of reducing the intended industry assistance rate from 27 per cent to nil. These amendments redefine the description of certain subheadings by replacing the word `wholly' with `of 100 per cent'. This will reinstate the intended level of assistance to the subject goods and corrects what appears to have been a drafting error in the original bill.

The third measure in the bill intends to make imports of unmanufactured tobacco and tobacco products free of customs duties from 1 January 1995. This action is a response to an Industry Commission report into the tobacco industry entitled The tobacco growing and manufacturing industry. The existing provisions are said to be against the rules of the World Trade Organisation as they require importers of unmanufactured tobacco to blend a certain amount of Australian tobacco with the imported tobacco.

However, aside from the fact that the Australian government is moving to drop a 50 per cent local content requirement at a time when the United States government is believed to be attempting to introduce regulations requiring 75 per cent local content for domestic and export tobacco products, the fact remains that the bill aims to reduce tax on a product that has contributed to the deaths of tens of thousands of Australians. The Democrats certainly do not support this reduction of taxation on tobacco and will be voting against this part of the bill.

The final part of the bill deals with the duty payable on automatic regulating or controlling instruments and apparatus. Schedule 2 of the bill will insert new general provisions that will have the effect of distinguishing between such goods used as replacement components in passenger vehicles and those used in other ways. This amendment provides a new tariff subheading to allow parts for regulating and controlling instruments which are not of a kind used as replacement components in passenger motor vehicles to retain the duty phase down to five per cent by 1 July 1996. The Democrats will not be opposing this amendment.

PARA.TAB: I just wish to make a brief statement about the Greens' position. Industry Commission report No. 34 of 1994 provided an opportunity for the Senate to look at and speak about the elimination of subsidies and protection to the Australian tobacco industry. This bill cuts the tariff on unmanufactured tobacco only. This is unlikely to affect the cost of tobacco products. Unmanufactured tobacco is a minor economic input to cigarettes. TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments to be moved to this bill. For the information of honourable senators, this memorandum was circulated in the chamber on 19 September 1995.

PARA.TAB: The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Vanstone, I wish to declare that I have an interest in the passage of this bill. The bill makes several changes to the law relating to proprietary companies. I am a secretary/director of a proprietary company in which I hold a shareholding and a non-shareholder/director of another proprietary company. While I do not consider matters in the bill are of major controversy, I still consider it is appropriate to advise the committee that my duties as a director of each of these companies may be affected by the passage of this legislation. The question is that the bill stand as printed.

—It is probably true to say that anyone who has some shares or any involvement in a company somewhere has some interest. I make an appropriate declaration myself in that respect. Anybody associated with any investments that have some sort of company association has, directly or indirectly, some interest in relation to this bill.

PARA.TAB: The coalition has no desire to delay any further the passage of this bill and we seek to make clear two things. We do not regard anything we have done thus far as delaying; we, in fact, thank the government for giving us some extra time during the parliamentary break to further investigate certain matters and, following that, subsequent to the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities having had the opportunity to have a second look at some matters, giving us the opportunity to give serious consideration to what they recommended as being the appropriate changes.

We did not think it was unreasonable to ask for a bit of extra time to sort those matters out, as they had been brought to our attention and became clearer later in the proceedings. We are grateful that the government was sensible enough to accommodate that, so there was no unnecessary delay with other matters.

Having said that, my office has indicated to the government, the Greens and the Democrats that we propose one simple amendment—although I suppose nothing is simple in relation to this bill. But what the amendment seeks to achieve is simple. We agree that lessening the load on those companies that would now be classified as small is a worthwhile experiment—perhaps it can be called an experiment. A reduction of the burden on small business must be welcomed, and an opportunity to put that to the test is being presented by this legislation. This notion underpins the government's small/large distinction, which is that large companies should have a greater burden than small companies.

Up until the end of the last sittings, we were of the view that the government's formula was perhaps right. Subsequent to those sittings, we have had the opportunity to rethink and consult more people. While we agree that a more useful way to look at requirements of reporting and requirements of corporate governance is whether a company is small or large, we do not agree that the standard for large companies needs to be higher than the existing standard.

In other words, we accept a small/large distinction, but we simply say this: `We will accept the standard that you offer for the small companies but, with respect to the large companies, we think they could stay the same.' That would leave small companies with a lesser burden and large companies with a higher burden. All we are talking about now is what the burden for the larger companies should be.

The government proposes some differentiation across those companies that would be classified as large, with one exception. That is, the government is now saying that those companies which were in existence in 1994 and which chose to have an auditor—remembering of course that those companies had a choice to either have an auditor or file key financial data—will be allowed to continue to have an auditor, provided they meet the other requirements of an exempt proprietary company, and they will not have to file financial statements. In other words, they can be quarantined with the choice that they made at the time to have an auditor. All those companies which did not make that choice and which chose only to file key financial data, as well as any subsequent companies that fall into the large basket, would have to have not only an auditor but also higher reporting requirements—that is, they would have to file financial statements.

It is not true to say that the government's proposal completely streamlines reporting for those companies that would be classified as large. It does not. It sets aside those companies which made what the government perceives to be the appropriate choice and appointed an auditor. For a number of reasons which the government might care to elaborate on, it believes that they can stay as they are and they will not have this higher filing of financial statements. So there is that differentiation within the government's proposal to deal with large, exempt proprietary companies.

We are asking the government to rethink this and put on a fresh set of glasses—which will actually be the old set of glasses it had on before it went into the simplification program—and say to itself, `For small companies, the lower requirements are appropriate and, for large companies, there should be a higher requirement.' But the higher requirement should be the requirement that existed before—to either have an auditor or file key financial data. That would simplify the reporting process such that we could say that all current exempt proprietary companies and those that fell into that category would have the same reporting requirements. We would not need this quarantining and grandfathering of those companies which chose to have an auditor prior to 1994.

We think that is the appropriate path to take. We are not convinced that there is adequate evidence to say that requiring an auditor in these large companies will save numerous companies from falling over. One could go back into the dark history of the 1980s and point to numerous occasions where auditors were in place and there was no saving against any bad faith or malfeasance on behalf of directors and there was no saving against management's stupidity vis-a-vis investments. Many auditors are now looking down the barrel of being sued because it has not turned out to be as effective as so many people hoped it would be.

I do not say that to indicate that we believe auditing is a useless process; clearly, it is not a useless process. But it is not the be-all and end-all either. On that basis we say, `Why don't we stick with the existing arrangement and allow those companies that are prudent—' in my view `—vis-a-vis their own assets to choose?' Certainly, if I had $10 million in turnover going through a company in which I had a shareholding, I would want an auditor if only to make sure that the management who come in and perhaps have no interest are not creaming off some of that money. That is the choice I would make, but other people would make a different choice. That is a matter we have left to them in the past. We do not believe the case has been made for changing it.

In summary—I do not think I need to elaborate on it any more—we agree the reporting requirements should be different for small companies than they are for large. We agree with a reduction in the reporting requirements of small companies. We do not believe that it is appropriate—and it does not automatically follow, in our view—to raise the reporting requirements for those large companies that the government proposes to raise the reporting requirements for. It would be simpler to say, `You can stay as you are. You will have, therefore, a higher reporting requirement than the small companies, because you will have to either have an auditor or file key financial data. That is a higher standard and it is the standard you have had all along.'

In conclusion, I point out that there has been some concern over the Corporations Law simplification process—not much, I agree; by and large, we hear almost nothing but praise for the process that has been gone through and for the recommendations in the first bill. We are now in the process of consulting on the second bill.

Some people have raised with us that it is a bit of a hoax to say that the process is one of simplification alone. Some people have taken that to mean that all that would happen, at most, would be putting it into plain English—which often means a larger bill but, nonetheless, something that everyone could readily understand—and perhaps a shifting around and consolidating such that the bill would be easier for people to read and to operate under.

Those people say to us—and they are right—with respect to the large exempt proprietary companies, `This is not a simplification at all; it is a substantive change to the law. It is an increase in a reporting requirement. It is a greater obligation on those businesses that there has not been an adequate case made out for.' In other words, they do not disagree with wanting the process of simplification to continue, but they simply point out that, just because you call it a simplification law, it does not follow that everything underneath it is. You have to watch what the substance of something is, and the substance of this increases the obligation and makes it more difficult for those companies to operate.

They say the case has not been made out and that they should be able to continue under the existing reporting requirements; that is, they will have to choose an auditor or they will have to file key financial statements. I suspect the government do not agree with that, but that is up to them. On that basis, I propose to move the amendment circulated in my name.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think a better course of action might be—if I may suggest—that the three government amendments, one of which is not truly an amendment, be moved first and then yours following that.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be supporting this amendment. We agree in substance with the government's legislation. We believe that the criteria that have been introduced in the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill are an improvement on the corporate entity test that has been used so far. PARA.TAB: We believe the strengthening of the exempting discretion of the ASC, the Australian Securities Commission, does cater for situations where the criteria might operate to place an additional load on a particular company. TALK.START.PARA: —I am a member of the corporations and securities committee that went through two reviews of this matter, including the definition of the small/large test. As my colleague Senator Vanstone said, we supported that definition. What has come to light in the last few days—since the committee made its report and the government made its recommendations—is that there is further evidence that some companies may be treated unfairly. PARA.TAB: You are proposing to exempt proprietary companies that are proposing to grandfather. There is a possibility that they will not have to report financial data by engaging an auditor. We have no problems with that. This would unfairly advantage a new company that moves into the large category in the next 12 months. It cannot, except by approaching the ASC, seek an exclusion. It will have to engage an auditor, as set out in the bill.

We think that the current system is a good one. It allows exempt companies in the large category, whether historically or in the future, to have a choice either of engaging an auditor and not reporting or of reporting key financial data. That is the system now.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure what you are asking me to give you a commitment on. In relation to Senator Vanstone's point that she raised at the end of her contribution, I can give an assurance that we will be looking at this distinction and reviewing it in two years time. PARA.TAB: I recognise that your amendment would draw a distinction between one group and another. The grandfathering is there for that good reason. The committee, in its deliberations, actually supported that.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not technically correct for you to present the situation that the needs of existing companies are catered for, as though you are grandfathering all. You are not.
—No. Don't take that as a generalisation.

—I just want to make that clear. The only ones you are grandfathering are the ones who chose to have an auditor. You are making a subjective test, as a government, as to those who should get the benefit of quarantining and those who should not. There may be some rationale, as you see it—but others would see no rationale in it—in saying that both these categories have complied with the law. One has filed key financial data. One has had an auditor. They have been lawfully going about their business. You are now saying that one crowd that did things lawfully can have reporting requirements and another crowd that was operating lawfully will have to have higher requirements.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —If there is concern about that distinction you can move an amendment to remove the grandfathering, but I am sure that is something you do not want to do. From my understanding, this process was something that was deliberated upon by the committee. This is the best the committee could come up with. It is something that we, on both sides, have shared acceptance of, apart from this late initiative.

—I just make the point that since the committee's deliberations it has been pointed out to us that a company which becomes large in future cannot go back in time and make use of the grandfathering clause. We see that as being unfair.
—You knew that before, though.

—I realise that, but it was not brought to attention. That is why Senator Vanstone has moved this amendment, to make it fair for all companies that are in the large category to have the existing system apply—either to audit and not report financial data or to report key financial data. I want to make sure the government understands that. We welcome your statement that there should be a review of these criteria for small/large tests and their threshold levels in future.

—It occurred to me that there is a fairly large anomaly. I want to seek some clarification before I work out exactly how big this anomaly is. Who has access to the information that is available as a result of these corporate audits?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that, other than for the grandfathered companies, the audited records would be lodged with the ASC and would then be available for public viewing.

—That makes the anomaly pretty complete, from what I can see. If you recall, we had some fairly substantial debates in this chamber about the levels of accountability for government business enterprises. Parliamentarians are not permitted to call for a full audit. The reason that is not accepted by the government is that it is commercial-in-confidence. This is taxpayers' money that is being used in a corporation. We are the shareholders. Members of the public are the shareholders. The government has consistently used commercial-in-confidence as the reason why those audits cannot take place, unless the minister calls for them. What is the difference between commercial-in-confidence that could allow a private company to be required to provide an audit that is publicly available and commercial-in-confidence for a government business enterprise?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I could be corrected here, but my understanding is that both government and private corporations that satisfy the large/small test would have to meet the requirements. Government corporations would also have to meet the requirements of the auditing which is proposed here, unless there is special legislation exempting it.
—The legislation exempts them.

—I do not think it exempts all of them. I think you will also find that the sort of information that you may have been requesting in respect of GBEs is a bit different from the audit provisions of this particular act. So keep that in mind as well.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take part in this debate because I feel very strongly about this. If there ever was an attack on small business, this is the attack that small business does not need. Let me put on the record that I am very grateful to Senator Vanstone for the way in which she has put the coalition position. I think it sends out a very clear message that both the Liberal Party and the National Party stand up 100 per cent behind small business.

PARA.TAB: I picked up what Senator Margetts just asked. Senator Margetts asked: who will be the recipient of this information? I think Senator Margetts wants to know—Senator Margetts, I would appreciate it if you would listen to this because the point I am trying to make is directed at you—what confidentiality do businesses have if they are required to put an audit report into the Australian Securities Commission. The answer to Senator Margetts is absolutely none.

If this bill goes through private companies, that are owned by members of their families, will have to disclose every asset, all their auditing figures, all their payroll—everything will have to be disclosed. What you are going to be asked to do—and I appreciate the Greens' stand on small business has always been consistent—is ask small business; that is, every person who runs a small business in Western Australia that has 50 employees or $5 million in assets or $10 million in turnover, to disclose every facet of their business for audit.

There would be significant numbers of small businesses out there. Let me tell you who they will be—just about every motor vehicle or tractor trader or machinery dealer in every town in Western Australia, and there are many small businesses in the hotel trade or the tourism trade. Roughly, off the top of my head, there would be about 4,000 or 5,000 small businesses in Western Australia. You will be asking them to put an audit down disclosing every facet of their business. That audit will go into the Australian Securities Commission and the Australian Securities Commission will make that audit public and anyone can access that—their competitor, big business.

For example, if a big business, a public company, is already paying audit fees and wants to find out how Fred Bloggs in the local hardware store is trading, all he has to do is role up to the Australian Securities Commission—I am not sure whether he would have to pay $5 or $10 or whatever—and he can get access to that person's books. I think that is totally unfair, totally unreasonable. Everything that will be detailed will be detailed at the Australian Securities Commission. You are taking away the whole privacy of that person's business. That is a consideration. I think that is where you were coming from when you were directing the questions to Senator Bolkus.

Let me go further than that. There are many small businesses. Let me give you the statistics. Out of every 100 businesses that start, 92 per cent are gone in eight years. Some are taken over, some get bigger, some get bought out, some go broke but at the end of six or seven years out of the 100 starters there are only eight left. Some of those businesses even manage to grow when they can employ 50 people, even manage to grow when they have $5 million in assets, even manage to grow when they have a turnover of $10 million, and that is not an excessive turnover.

Those big small businesses, those private companies, are the backbone of Australian small business. When we get into the rural towns and towns that depend on primary industry, they are the great employers of those towns. They are the big employers. They are the people at the local Mitre 10 store, the GMH dealer, the machinery dealer, the grain dealer. They employ maybe half the total number of employees in a town. If we go along with the government, you are going to ask them to pay an additional $25,000 to $30,000 for an audit when they are already getting their tax done. They are already getting an accountancy firm to do their figures now.

Their profit and loss figures and their balance sheets are required. The tax agent does that for them. He then prepares an income tax assessment. He sends that along to the Taxation Office and the Taxation Office assesses how much tax he has to pay. Small businesses are, in effect, having taxation review their books.

Let me pick up the Democrats' amendment. I shudder to think when small businesses enhance the Democrats. I have never heard anything so insane and inane as Senator Spindler's statement that he is helping them to manage their business by insisting, by legislation, that they get an audit done.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should have come to the review.

—I spent 20 years of my life in small business. I know what I am talking about and that is the most incompetent, stupid statement I have ever heard in this parliament. You ought to hang your head in shame for even daring to say it. You, with no business experience in your life, are telling small business how to run their business.
—You're actually wrong, senator.

—If you have ever run a business I would be surprised. You could not run a chook raffle. Here we have the Democrats setting themselves up as the conscience of small business in Australia. They know better than small business. They all know about it. Senator Lees is a teacher. The leader of the Democrats is a teacher.
—Nothing wrong with teachers.

—There is certainly nothing wrong with teachers. My wife is a teacher, but I would not ask my wife to come in here and talk on small business. I do not think Senator Spindler is competent to talk on small business. You are not only pushing them to the limit by making small business pay between $12,000 to $15,000 to $40,000 extra but you are opening up the confidentiality of their business, and then you are saying we are doing it because we know better than you. I just find this very hard and very difficult to believe.

PARA.TAB: This First Corporate Law Simplification Bill started out to assist small business, but we have bred a Frankenstein creation. All we have done is saddle them with another $30,000 to $40,000 worth of costs with the excuse we are here to help. If there were ever a truth—I am from the government and I am here to help; I am only going to charge you another $30,000 to run your small business—this is one of the truisms of the Senate.

I just cannot believe that you would expose small business to such an incredible imbalance. Senator Spindler, you are hurting small business because you are allowing small business competitors, big business, to know exactly what small businesses are worth, to know exactly what their turnover is, to know exactly what is happening in the towns.

Let me put it another way. Say there is a Holden dealership in Warrnambool that is doing very nicely. It is a local dealership and it has been part of the town, assisting the town, for 50 years. A big company wants to come down and set up there. They look at a map, see there are 100,000 people in Warrnambool and that it is a big enough district to sustain business.

What do they do? They just walk into the Australian Securities Commission and say, `We want to look at that particular business. We don't need to take it over. We don't need to offer them anything. We will just find out what they do, what their turnover is and we will go in and set up beside them. Not only that, we will undercut them and take over their business.' If ever there were anything detrimental to small business, it is this bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Having listened to you, Senator Boswell, I must say that your contribution was forceful but wrong—totally wrong—and in all honesty, you should acknowledge that yourself. We have here a distinction in the legislation that has been worked through comprehensively by two processes in this place—two joint parliamentary committee processes. Throughout those processes there was extensive consultation.

PARA.TAB: We are talking about making the audit rules that now apply to public companies also apply to large proprietary companies. That is nothing new. That is something that has been known from day one with this legislation—making the same audit requirements applicable to large proprietary companies.

This is not the sort of intrusive stuff that Senator Boswell was talking about, breeding fear and loathing in Warrnambool and other regional areas. These are the same audit requirements that currently apply to public corporations, the information derived from which is available to be seen. We do not want the situation that we had in the 1980s. Given the size and the turnover of assets of the larger companies, we recognise that it is not appropriate that larger companies be able to opt out and decide whether or not to lodge key financial data.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think you understand it.

—The other thing about our requirement is that it recognises that if people have sufficient and timely information we will not have the problems we had in the 1980s. What Senator Hill does not understand is the background to this legislation.

PARA.TAB: The federal government is setting a benchmark that everyone who has been part of the process—this has been discussed by all sides of parliament through a joint parliamentary inquiry—would recognise is much more generous than those applying in other countries with similar legislation. I am not referring to countries that we do not normally compare ourselves with. Our test here is much more generous than those used in other comparable countries for determining when a company must have its accounts audited.

In Canada, a non-public company has to have its accounts audited if its assets exceed $2.5 million or if its gross operating revenue exceeds $5 million. In Australia, it is either $10 million revenue or $5 million assets, which is much more generous than in Canada. In the UK, any company with an annual turnover of more than $700,000 has to have its accounts audited.

In addition, a UK company which satisfies two of the following criteria in the preceding year is also required to have its accounts audited: a turnover in excess of #2.8 million, which is $5.7 million, a balance sheet total that shows assets of more than $2.89 million—on both scores, we are much more generous—or with 50 or more employees, with which we are in sync.

Evidence before the committee indicated that the new audit requirements are not that much different at all. What we are asking for with this bill is something that is much more generous than other countries afford, and something which is not intrusive.

If you want a situation where key financial data is supplied to the ASC up to seven months after it is compiled—all the information is out of date before it becomes part of the public record—fair enough. Stand up for it. The Greens will stand up with you. But, despite being hit with this last minute sting, the government and the committee are about recognising the need for more current, more relevant information being obtained in a non-intrusive manner.

If you want to do a flip on this proposal, stand up and be counted and say, `Let's do away with it.' That was not the tenor of the Senator Vanstone's discussion. She was much more accommodating. In respect of the Greens, I must say, if you want a situation of less transparency—

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you intimidate the Greens.
—You intimidated both of us, Senator Boswell. You interrupted our conversation a few moments ago in a very rude manner. I was offended by it.
—I am sorry if I caused the minister any offence. I withdraw it.

—And I am sorry if I caused you any offence. But the point I am making is that it has been an acceptable part of the proposal from the parliamentary committees that we have a trigger that is much more generous and that recognises the need for much more up-to-date information. If there is to be a flip at the last moment, let the record show it, but the government opposes this particular move very strenuously.

—There are still some points on which I seek clarification. I was not able to be involved with the committee process because of other commitments. It is quite ironic then that the government put out releases at a press conference indicating that the Greens were responsible for these benefits not being afforded to business. I wonder whether business would have been happy if this bill had been pushed through last session without some of these issues being debated.

PARA.TAB: During the process, has there been a full analysis of the relative public interest benefits as opposed to possible cost benefits to business? If so, what was the methodology and is there a report that indicates that the implications here have been looked at carefully?

I also want to know whether such audits would require the statement of the value of particular assets? Would such audits require an indication that would allow other people to work out the margins on the cost of production of particular items? Turnover and profit were mentioned but I would like to know whether such things as the value of particular assets and the production margins would be part of such audits?

TALK.START.PARA: —It would not be part of the financial statements that would be reported.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Vanstone. That is the answer I would give to the second part of the question.
—Is there anything else we can do for you?

—There is, actually, but I will not tell you what that is right now. With respect to the first part of the question, the ASC has the power to make exemptions in particular circumstances where the cost of complying with the requirements would seem to outweigh the benefits.

PARA.TAB: I want to put on the record the fact that this proposal has gone through a lot of consultation with relevant industry groups and interest groups and that at the end of the day there was genuine support for it. That support reflects the fact that people see its worth and that the benefits would outweigh the costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —In such audits, would the value of particular assets need to be noted down? Also, from such audits, would somebody have the ability to calculate the margins on production?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice in respect of both of those questions is that the answer is no, Senator Margetts. There will not be a need to specify the value of specific assets. In respect of your second question, the answer is no as well. The audit requirements are not that cumbersome.

Progress reported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.
