SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very prompt report, and I congratulate the Australian Sports Drug Agency for the speed with which it has reported to the Senate. Also, I commend the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) and his office for not holding this report up for the inordinate amount of time that so many ministers seem to hold up their reports. This report was signed on 12 September by my cousin and former colleague, Professor Peter Baume, as Chairperson of the Australian Sports Drug Agency, and here we are, still in September, actually dealing with it. I commend everyone involved. I feel I should do that in view of the times I have criticised the late presentation of these reports. We are going to be inundated with these reports as the year progresses, so it is good to see that some people are prepared to assist the Senate and present these speedily.

PARA.TAB: The interesting thing about the Australian Sports Drug Agency is the outstanding lead it is giving in the fight against drugs in sport. In the latest financial year, the agency conducted 3,108 tests, which is up on the 2,002 in the previous year, and it covered 49 sports. There were 819 tests for professional sport leagues, particularly the New South Wales Rugby League, the Australian Football League, the National Basketball League, the National Soccer League and the Queensland Rugby League. This was a considerable increase from the 667 tests of the previous year. In other words, these major professional sports are increasingly using, mainly on a user-pays basis, the services of the Australian Sports Drug Agency.

The agency recorded 25 positive test results, which represented about 1.09 per cent of all tests. This was a lower percentage and a lower number than the previous year, even though more tests were made. In the previous year there were 33 positive tests, which represented 1.18 per cent of all tests.

Sporting organisations established that 10 of the 25 positive test results were due to the inadvertent or legitimate therapeutic use of banned substances, and the overall instance of positive drug tests for the use of prohibited substances, such as anabolic steroids and diuretics, was 0.26 per cent, compared to 0.57 per cent in the previous year. In other words, it has been halved. That is an outstandingly good result, and I commend everyone involved for the fact that there has been a halving of the overall incidence of positive drug tests for the use of prohibited substances.

However, almost double the number of competitors refused to comply with the request to provide a sample, and that is a trend that is in the opposite direction and is most unfortunate. Nine competitors failed to do so compared to five in 1993-94, and I hope that severe action is taken against those who fail to provide such tests.

In fact, in a very interesting table at the back of the report at page 102, there is shown to be an enormous number of situations where the penalty for failing to comply with a drug test has not yet been advised to the Australian Sports Drug Agency by the sport involved. While I commend power-lifting and weight-lifting for some severe penalties they have imposed on those people who have been found to have had adverse tests—for example, in power-lifting, I think there were six altogether—the fact is that a failure to advise what has happened is not sending the right message. The message that has to be given is that severe action is taken against those who fail to provide a sample.

I also mention that there are quite significant differences in the sorts of penalties between sports. For example, the sport that I am closest to and that I have the most knowledge of, I guess, is soccer football, and I am interested to note that a failure to comply only involved a 12-month suspension; whereas in power-lifting, a failure to comply brought about a three-year suspension. It may well have been a repeat offence, but there is clearly a need, it seems to me, for greater similarity between sports in the severity of penalties involving these offences. I hope these sports do speak to each other about this sort of thing. Also, there should be greater advice quicker. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight with some good news: that the taxpayers of Australia have been relieved of the costs of supporting 44 people who illegally entered this country at the back end of last year and the beginning of this year. Forty-four Sino-Vietnamese people were returned to Haikou in China by aircraft this morning out of Port Hedland, which represents the sixth movement of these people who illegally entered the country last year.

PARA.TAB: It shows to the Senate—and, indeed, to the people of Australia—that the memorandum of understanding that was entered into between the Australian government and the government of the People's Republic of China is working. Under the terms of that memorandum of understanding, there have now been 369 people returned to their adopted homeland, because they have previously been granted refugee status in China.

That represents a very significant saving to the Australian taxpayer. It costs some $55 per day, per person to maintain a person at the Port Hedland detention centre. Now that 369 people have been returned, that is saving the taxpayers of Australia some $20,000 per day that they were previously paying for each and every one of those 369 people who illegally came into this country and who illegally sought to abuse the compassion that Australia has for those who are in less fortunate circumstances than ourselves.

I look forward to the further movements and removals of people. There is still quite a large number that remain in detention in this country at great cost not only to the Australian taxpayer but also to themselves. These people who remain in detention can leave at any time and, if they choose to remain in detention and choose to keep their children in detention—that is the thing that I cannot forgive them for—I think it says something about them as parents.

I will draw just very brief attention to another article that appeared on the AAP wire service later on today. The first one, which told us about the removals, appeared at 11.57 today. Then it was followed, for some reason that I am not sure of, at 15.29 by another one entitled `Sino-Vietnamese to appeal Federal Court ruling: boat people lead'.

I do not know why this article has appeared now because the decision about this appeal was announced some weeks ago. The announcement of the appeal caused somewhat of a furore back home in Western Australia and has led to the Attorney-General in Western Australia announcing that there is to be a high level appeal into the operations of the Legal Aid Commission of Western Australia.

The Legal Aid Commission of WA is the legal body which has taken up this appeal on behalf of 118—I think it is that many; it certainly is over 100—Sino-Vietnamese people who arrived here on the albatross boat. They are expending great amounts of taxpayers' money on this through a commission which, on its own word of mouth, is strapped for cash and in the last financial year has had to reject some 5,550 applications for legal assistance. We now have an inquiry going into the Legal Aid Commission to see where the money could be better spent than it has perhaps been in the past.

It is interesting that an appeal is going to be lodged. If one reads the decision of Mr Justice O'Loughlin, who delivered the decision on 27 July, one would find it unbelievable that an appeal could be launched against such a decision. These people asserted that, prior to the declaration by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) on 30 December last year that they were not going to apply for refugee status, they had in fact claimed refugee status. When they were questioned in court, they did not even know the Chinese words for `asylum' or `refugee'. For that and a whole number of other reasons Mr Justice O'Loughlin tossed out their application.

In the brief time available I also want to make some reference to a couple of other groups of illegal boat people who have arrived in this country and remained in detention, at great cost to the Australian taxpayer and of course at great cost to themselves. Mr Justice Sundberg, in the Federal Court on Thursday, 31 August 1995, rejected the claims by four Cambodian boat people that the minister's delegate had made an error in law in not granting them refugee status.

The reason I mention this case is that last week in Perth there was a demonstration outside the state office of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to say that this decision is wrong and that the minister should grant those people humanitarian status in Australia. I have read Mr Justice Sundberg's statement. I again find amazing these people who, in breach of orders, claim and take advantage of us all the way through. They get fed, kept and looked after from go to woe and then go into our courts and make exaggerated claims like they could be disadvantaged, if they are returned to Cambodia, because of their religion.
In regard to some of the people, His Honour said in his judgment that in relation to applicant one—I am choosing to use the pseudo names:

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think there was any factual basis for the (applicant one's) claim. The material before the delegate was that the applicant did not practise any Chinese customs or religion. She was not taught the Chinese religion, "but may be Buddhist".
That is the applicant's quote. Regarding applicant two, His Honour said:
. . . did not really care about practising Chinese religion or customs and there was not factual basis for his claim of feared persecution.
In relation to applicant three, His Honour said:
. . . he cannot speak Chinese, and not being able to practise the Chinese religion does not worry him because he is not very religious.

I am appalled that people are able to continue to make these claims. Other people who have received some attention, including from my colleague Senator Chamarette, are two Cambodian brothers who arrived in this country in June 1990, made application for refugee status, had their application considered, were rejected, appealed that decision, were rejected, made an application again, were rejected, appealed the decision again and were rejected—four rejections.

PARA.TAB: They had two claims before the Federal Court of Australia; they pulled the claims out of the Federal Court of Australia. They are still in detention in Australia. They have not sought to take advantage of the concessions that the minister arranged in 1993—that, if they were returned to their homeland of Cambodia and stayed there for a year, they could make application for permanent residency in Australia. Many Cambodians have done so. Many have taken up that option and are now settled in Australia, rearing their families and living in good health and good conditions. These particular individuals chose not to do that. Now they are about to be deported because they have exhausted all the time and opportunities for appeals against the decision.

In an article in the West Australian of 6 September this year it was reported, under the headline `Senator appeals for Cambodians', that Senator Chamarette has come out in support of those brothers. I think the minister ought to take some action on both these things. I think that the Cambodian brothers should be sent home and the minister should make available to Senator Chamarette, out of his budget, enough money for an airfare for her to go to Cambodia to live with them to ensure that they are not persecuted in their homeland.

Many hundreds of thousands of people have gone back to Cambodia and have not been persecuted. If Senator Chamarette cares so much about these people, she ought to show just how much she cares and, at no financial cost to her, she should go to Cambodia with the two brothers and make sure, on behalf of the Australian taxpayer—(Time expired)

I will pursue the other remarks at some later time.

PARA.TAB: I rise to draw to the attention of honourable senators the human rights violations and acts of war which continue against the people of Bougainville. I quote from a Pax Christi International publication:

SPEECH.PARA: The civil war on Bougainville is the story of the victory of the political and economic interests of colonial overlords over principles of human rights and the right to self-determination. This, the UN Decade of Indigenous Peoples has witnessed four of the six years of civil war and suffering on the North Solomon Island of Bougainville but the world has paid little attention. The situation is a complex one and is often further obscured by the dangerously simplistic nature of the debate at times, e.g. in the Australian and Papua New Guinean press and elsewhere. This is due to the communication's blockade on Bougainville which has created an information vacuum.

I wish to acknowledge the presence of Moses and Marilyn Havini in the public gallery. I draw to the attention of senators that Marilyn Taleo Havini has compiled a list of some of the instances of human rights abuses that have come to light between the years 1989 and 1995. She acknowledges that the list is not able to be as comprehensive or exhaustive as she would wish.

PARA.TAB: To make sure we do not assume that this publication is a dry and theoretical listing of human tragedy, I have been asked to read a letter which was sent to Marilyn by one of her friends on Bougainville which, I believe, gives us a very visual picture of the sorrow of people there. I read it in full:

SPEECH.PARA: Dearest Merilyn,

PARA.TAB: Aleluia! I thank Heaven for this beautiful opportunity to write to you. I hope this letter reaches you in good health.

In B/ville we're living a very hard life. In fact it is like Jesus going again to Calvary. We have lost everything. We're hiding in the mountains of Panguna. Everyday, the noise of mortar is following us. There are sick people everywhere, unattended to. People are hungry all the time. People are dying everywhere without receiving any medical care whatsoever.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend the publication Marilyn Havini has put together, and ask that senators look at it. In a short while I am going to seek leave to table it. I express my appreciation for her dedication and diligence in trying to draw together the information that will be of value to all organisations involved in pursuing human rights. Her work seeks to begin a process which will allow further information to be gathered and to address the communication blockade referred to in the Pax Christi quote. I have asked Marilyn Havini to make a short statement as to why she came to publish this book. I seek leave to incorporate, in her own words, how she has come to do that.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: "The 1995 compilation of Human Rights Abuses in Bougainville (1989-1995) has been printed this year in response to numerous requests for copies of my initial hand typed document. I had prepared the document as initial preparation for the failed 1994 October 10th Peace Conference. Various Human Rights Organisations (including International Red Cross, Medicines Sans Frontiers, Amnesty International, International Commission of Jurists, UNPO, IWIGIA, Pax Christi and numerous Churches) have sought the material when they discovered that such a document was in existence.

This detailed compilation of gross human rights violations has been assembled in a chronological format and contains reports of a horror that has not been seen in Bougainville, PNG since World War II.

In discussion with lawyers who were assisting the 1994 negotiated Peace Conference towards a political settlement, I expressed my concern for the necessity to address Justice and basic Human Rights issues. Having lived with the people in Bougainville for over 20 years, I knew that the politics that caused the war were born from Government (both PNG and the former Australian) refusal to address basic issues of Justice.

In Bougainville, I lived through the 1989 invasions of both Australian trained PNG Riot Police and PNG Defence Forces on an all but defenceless civilian population. We experienced harassment and cried with others as their human rights were systematically denied in an attempt to cower them into submission. I watched helplessly as the children I taught in High School slipped away into the jungle to join a growing band of Bougainvilleans in forming a Revolutionary Army.

Now in Australia, I have been on the receiving end of information from inside Bougainville for five years. I have watched the inhumanity compounded, the suffering recounted as isolated incidents in the form of press releases that were too often ignored by the media.
Human Rights issues must be properly addressed for there to be any lasting peace in Bougainville.

This listing of human rights abuses is as comprehensive as has been possible, although it is far from complete. It is an attempt to make a starting point for people to come to terms with what has really happened to them. Most of the material has not been available to the general public previously. I have included all violations that can be traced through date and contact source. My hope is that it will become known, not because it is sensational reading, but with the prayer that we will all work to stop the continued violations and murder.

I plan to issue updates to this document on a regular basis so that the most accurate and detailed account of the human suffering on Bougainville is available for examination. I would be grateful for any additional information, corrections and counter claims for future publication.
(Signed) Marilyn Taleo Havini

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight, I wish to emphasise two issues. Firstly, I believe Australia is rapidly moving to being a dictatorship. Why do I say that? Because so many prominent Australians are increasingly reluctant to air their views, particularly where those views are likely to be in conflict with the prevailing views of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

PARA.TAB: Perhaps the latest example of this is a situation involving the respected Dr Vince FitzGerald, a former high-ranking bureaucrat from Treasury and now a consultant in the private sector. All honourable senators would know that Dr FitzGerald has taken a public role in highlighting the lack of savings in Australia. This attack on Dr FitzGerald is not an isolated incident. The sort of intimidation that increasingly we are seeing on prominent Australians who take a position contrary to that of the government is indeed a worry to all those Australians who are in favour of open, frank and free speech in this country.

We have a Prime Minister who deliberately set out to denigrate the professional reputation of Dr FitzGerald amongst Dr FitzGerald's colleagues and peers. A person of lesser courage, conviction and intellect would have been muzzled by the Prime Minister's action. I think it is testimony to his character and his reputation that, despite that, Dr FitzGerald has hit back and firmly restated his position.

The second saga is the entry of Bernie Fraser into the debate. I do not mind that at all. It is not what Bernie Fraser said that I believe is so important. That got the news notoriety. The real issue is what Bernie Fraser did not say. I think it is unfortunate that he gave such a one-sided perspective, given his high economic training in this particular area.

The point at issue is whether the high level of Australian debt impacts on interest rates in this country. It may be true that in the 18 most recent interest rates decisions of the Reserve Bank the level of indebtedness may not have been a factor. But allow me to use an analogy. Essentially, Australia is cruising along in a car in overdrive. The problem is that as soon as we get to a hill, we may not have sufficient lower gears to get us up or over the hill. That is the issue.

In recent years there has not been a lot of pressure from international interest rate movements because international interest rates have been relatively benign. While they are benign, it is true that monetary conditions, et cetera, perhaps and certainly do play a more significant role in determining the level of interest rates in Australia. The problem is that when the situation changes—it will never continue perhaps as it is now, because we do have our ups and downs—the risk factor is certainly increased. That is important. We are increasingly putting Australia more at risk. While it may be true that today that risk factor may not be overly significant, when things start to stall a little bit that risk factor becomes a lot higher.

You only have to consider your own personal situation. If you overborrow and property values drop, you are going to be very vulnerable. On the other hand, those who have a lower level of gearing, less borrowings and a lower level of risk can ride out any potential storm.

Essentially, we are in a situation where Australia has very large international indebtedness. When the Labor Party came to office, it was a mere $34 billion. It is now in excess of $150 billion. The risk factor is climbing. Should international rates change and rise, Australia is going to be in the first line of risk.

The other issue is: why has it been necessary for Australia to have such a high level of indebtedness? This must come back to the policies pursued by Labor governments, because they have created conditions under which it was not affordable for so many Australians to borrow in Australia, so they went overseas and ran the risk of adverse exchange movements.

Perhaps I should repeat some words that a former leader of the opposition, John Hewson, constantly used to remind the Australian electorate. He said, `Today, through the actions of this government Australians are passing on to their successors a lower standard of living than we enjoy.'

For those who travel overseas the deteriorating exchange rates between Australia and other countries—for example, Singapore—are a worry. Regrettably, Australian affordability is slipping, and our relative purchasing ability is declining when compared with that of a number of years ago. The sorts of countries to which we must travel in terms of affordability for limited resources are perhaps the lesser performing countries or those which are emerging from the Eastern bloc. It is a sad scenario.

If we examine Australia's savings level—it is around 17 per cent of gross domestic product—it is an abysmally low figure. Not so long ago it dropped to about 16 per cent. That is the lowest Australia has had since the two world wars and the Great Depression—and we certainly do not want that repeated. But if we look at comparable countries, Singapore, for example, which in 35 years has performed an economic miracle, Singapore now has a savings rate of 48 per cent to gross domestic product—a far cry from our figure.

Madam Deputy President, the real issue I wish to emphasise and leave with you tonight is in two parts: firstly, that the risk premium on foreign debt is priced into the whole structure of interest rates, which cannot be denied; secondly, and also not to be denied, is that that risk factor is increasing. Therefore, should there be a change in the terms of trade or the value of the exchange rate et cetera, increasingly Australians will be in trouble from the perspective of uncontrolled increases in interest rates.

What was interesting from Bernie Fraser's remarks, although not so widely reported, was `that everything is really linked up with everything else'. In that sentence there is a connection between foreign debt and interest rates. I suppose that is where the head of the Reserve Bank used his escape clause. So I leave you with the comment: it is not what Bernie Fraser said but what he did not say which is the thrust of my contribution and those omissions must be a real worry to the people of Australia.

PARA.TAB: (i) Defence does not keep records in a form that enables the question to be answered with accuracy. This is because the data is based on the place of payment rather than the state to which the payment is being directed. The expenditure data can also be distorted as some payments are made to contractors' head office which can be located in states and territories removed from where the contract work is being performed.

(ii) Certain other elements of Defence expenditure, including some capital equipment payments, are handled centrally. As a consequence, the expenditure profiles for some states and territories are distorted. For example, certain payments associated with the New Submarine, JORN and the Geraldton communications facility are paid in the ACT.

(iii) Expenditure on Service salaries can also be unreliable as portion of the payments are made to banks in the state branch where the member's account is domiciled rather than the state where the member is posted. Additionally, banks do not recognise the ACT and the Northern Territory as head offices (in Defence's accounting system these payments are recorded against New South Wales and South Australia respectively).

(iv) The ACT figures have increased substantially since 1993-94 due to increased superannuation contributions; the impact of the increase in the effective rate of Fringe Benefits Tax; and the introduction of Accrual Based Superannuation payments.
(v) Defence spending overseas and payments made in foreign currencies through the Department of Finance Regional Office Canberra have been excluded from these figures.

ANSWER.PARA: (2)DEFENCE FUNCTION OUTLAYS ACHIEVEMENT BY PROGRAM (INCLUDES OVERSEAS EXPENDITURE AND DEFENCE RECEIPTS)

PARA.TAB: (i) Defence Force Retirements and Death Benefits and the Military Superannuation and Benefits Scheme were moved to Non Defence Function from financial year 1992-93 and this explains the reduction in the Forces Executive Program expenditure levels after 1991-92.

(ii) The reduction for the Industry Involvement and Contracting Sub-Program of the Acquisition and Logistics Program from financial year 1990-91 onwards is due principally to reduced transitional funding for Aerospace Technologies of Australia and Australian Defence Industries.

(iii) The reduction in expenditure levels in the Budget and Management Program from 1993-94 onwards is principally due to the attribution of Fringe Benefits Tax payments to Programs which in turn helps explain some of the increases in those Programs.

ANSWER.PARA: (3) PROPORTION OF DEFENCE FUNCTION OUTLAYS ACHIEVED IN WESTERN AUSTRALIA

PARA.TAB: (i) The proportion of the Budget spent in Western Australia has been adjusted for the effect of the introduction in 1993-94 of Accrual Based Superannuation payments; the increase in the effective rate of Fringe Benefits Tax from 1994-95; and the non-recurrence of one-off expenditure relating to capital facilities projects and ship refits in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 1 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the Australian Industrial Registry require registered trade unions to submit annual returns, including financial statements; if so, is that information public.

(2) Is this information accessible in a manner similar to Australian Security Commission annual returns of companies; if so, can copies be provided of the annual returns, including financial statements, for all registered trade unions for the 1992-93, 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Organisations registered under the Industrial Relations Act 1988 are required to regularly lodge in the Australian Industrial Registry various returns including financial statements—most of these documents may be inspected by the public.
(2) Access to these documents is prescribed in Industrial Relations Regulations 127 and 131 which provide that a document may be inspected, upon

ANSWER.PARA: giving reasonable notice, at a registry on ordinary working days between 9.30 a.m. and 4.30 p.m. and a person may, upon application, obtain an office copy or a certified copy of any such document subject to a fee for the recovery of costs.

PARA.TAB: To obtain the information sought would involve the Registry in considerable research and I am not prepared to authorise the time and resources entailed in collecting the information.
